name: Brown, Sen Bob
text:
—I move:
(1)	 Page 2 (after line 20), after clause 3, insert:
4 Racial Discrimination Act
	 (1)	 Without limiting the general operation of the Racial Discrimination Act 1975  in relation to the provisions of the Native Title Act 1993 , the provisions of the Racial Discrimination Act 1975  are intended to prevail over the provisions of this Act.
	 (2)	 The provisions of this Act do not authorise conduct that is inconsistent with the provisions of the Racial Discrimination Act 1975 .
This is an amendment to give the Racial Discrimination Act aegis over the Native Title Amendment Bill that we are dealing with in committee today. The amendment uses almost the same wording as was endorsed by all parties in the Senate when amending the social security legislation bill in 1996. In that bill it was agreed to insert just such an amendment to ensure that the legislation would not be racially discriminatory. I move this amendment in similar words to ensure that this legislation will not be racially discriminatory.
The clear intent of the amendment—as it was the intent of Senator Margetts's amendment, which was defeated on Friday—is to ensure that the Racial Discrimination Act prevails so that we do not have discrimination as a result of the Native Title Amendment Bill. The question I put to other entities in this place is this: how can you argue against an amendment which will ensure that there will be no racial discrimination?
On Meet The Press yesterday, the shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs, Daryl Melham, 
 had this to say of the legislation coming through this place—which is satisfactory, as Labor sees it: `If we wanted to be destructive, we would be supporting the Greens' amendment, which is a clause-buster.'
The only way to take that is to understand that, like the government, and I presume Senate Harradine, the Labor Party will not be supporting this Greens' amendment because it busts racial discrimination in this legislation.
—That is not true.
—Senator Harradine says it is not true. I look forward to hearing his response. Through you, Madam Chair, I say to Senator Harradine that it is true.
—If you had read this document you wouldn't be saying that.
—I have read that document, and I am saying that, Senator Harradine. I am saying that the amendment that you will be supporting allows for racial discrimination. Senator Margetts made that clear, and there is eminent legal opinion which says the same. Professor Tony Blackshield, in commenting on Senator Margetts's amendment, made it clear that in his opinion the weak amendment coming up next does not do the job. It is not a clause-buster, Senator Harradine, through you, Madam Chair. It is not a clause-buster, as the Labor Party rightly described this one.
In this situation, we do need clause-busting legislation. If there is racial discrimination in this bill, and I say there is, let us bust it—let us call a spade a spade. Let us have an amendment here which will make sure there will be no racial discrimination.
If an amendment which Labor, Senator Harradine, the Liberal Party and the National Party voted for under the social security legislation was good enough then, please get up and explain, all of you, why it is not good enough for the indigenous people of this country. Why is this amendment not good enough to deal with the Wik 10-point plan which, I repeat, is racially discriminatory?
Through you, Madam Chair, conversely, if your 10-point plan is not discriminatory, Senator Minchin, then support this amend 
 ment. Why can't you support this amendment? What clause is there that needs busting, that you need to worry about? But you say there is none.
The Labor Party, the government and Senator Harradine say there is no racial discrimination, presumably, in the legislation—there are no clauses with discrimination. We all know that there are, but they say that there are not. So how can they argue against legislation which is tailor-made to seek out such discrimination and which gives the High Court the power to seek out such discrimination and knock it out of this bill if it is there? Instead of that, we have the Labor spokesman on the weekend saying, `We can't support that amendment from the Greens because it might clause-bust where there is racial discrimination.' Well, they are hoist with their own petard; they are uncovered by their own argument. There is no excuse for not supporting this amendment, as there was no excuse, in my books, for not supporting Senator Margetts's even stronger amendment of last week.
To each of those who will follow and who oppose this amendment, I will repeat the question: if it was good enough for you to back the social security legislation affecting all Australians, why is it not good enough for you to back this legislation which specifically affects the indigenous people of this country? Answer that!
Amendment not agreed to.

name: Bolkus, Sen Nick
text:
—I move:
Schedule 1, item 3, page 5 (lines 4 and 5), omit the item, substitute:
3  Section 7
	 Repeal the section, substitute:
7  Relationship with Racial Discrimination Act
	 (1)	 This Act is intended to be read and construed subject to the provisions of the Racial Discrimination Act 1975.
	 (2)	 Subsection (1) does not affect the validation of past acts or intermediate period acts by or in accordance with this Act.
		 Note:	 The provisions of the Racial Discrimination Act 1975  apply to the performance of functions and exercise of powers conferred by or authorised 
 by this Act. To construe this Act, and thereby to determine its operation, ambiguous terms should be construed consistently with the Racial Discrimination Act 1975  if that construction would remove ambiguity.
I spoke to this amendment at length on Friday. The amendment implements in totality, I would argue, the options under the Racial Discrimination Act in that it reflects what the Senate decided when we last debated this in December last year—that is, to ensure that this particular measure of the government, this legislation, could be tested against the Racial Discrimination Act but tested as a whole.
What is provided for in the RDA is a capacity to assess whether a piece of legislation is a special measure and, as such, may conform with the Racial Discrimination Act. That was the principle that was adopted by the Senate last time and that is the principle we are proposing this time with the additional clause that makes it very clear that section 7 will apply with respect to functions carried out under the act. It also makes it more clear that the clause is to be read to ensure assessment as to whether the legislation conforms with the special measure provision. It does not deem it but it ensures the capacity to so assess it.

name: Woodley, Sen John
text:
—I must say that this particular amendment puts the Democrats in a terrible situation because you are asking us to vote for something we voted against. Certainly, section 2 of this, which is the subsection that concerns me, is asking the Democrats to reverse a vote that we have already made in this chamber. Section 2 makes it very clear why the Labor Party wants to fall from the position they took in December and to move subsection 2 which allows them to wriggle out of the—
—You're wrong, John. That was moved in December, I'm sure. You're not talking about the clauses, are you?
—I am talking about subsection 2:
. . . does not affect the validation of past acts or intermediate period acts by or in accordance with this Act. 

—That was in.
—That is subsection 2?
—Yes, that was in.
—What I am saying is that we voted against the validation of past acts or intermediate period acts under the previous section. You are asking us now to vote for this, when we have—
—No, we actually accepted 7(2) last time; 7(2) is the same as last time.
—Senator Woodley, are you asking questions of Senator Bolkus?
—I will turn it into a question.

name: Bolkus, Sen Nick
text:
—What we did last time was to carry 7(1) and 7(2). The only change this time is the addition of the clause note; 7(2) as a substantive subclause was deliberated upon and carried last year. The clause note has a dual effect. It says:
The provisions of the Racial Discrimination Act 1975  apply to the performance of functions and exercise of powers conferred by or authorised by this Act.
It clarifies that. The second part of the clause note is:
To construe this Act, and thereby to determine its operation, ambiguous terms should be construed consistently with the Racial Discrimination Act 1975  if that construction would remove ambiguity.
It is the clause note that is the addition. I would argue that the clause note emboldens the operation of the RDA with respect to performance of functions and exercise of powers. I remind you that in the debate last time, the amendment—I think at that stage it was Senator Harradine's—was carried. The argument went along the lines that the amendment incorporating the RDA had the effect of ensuring that the legislation would have to be assessed as a whole as against the Racial Discrimination Act rather than on a one-by-one clause busting operation. So there is no difference in terms of the substantive clause or the interpretation given to it by the clause note.

name: Woodley, Sen John
text:
—Thank you for that explanation, 
 Senator Bolkus. I was on the wrong track, so I am happy to be pulled back but, in a sense, part of what I said still stands—that is, we have subsection 2 because of the vote for validation of those intermediate past acts. Clearly, it needs to be here so that we do not turn around and reverse the vote which was taken. I was simply pointing out that the Democrats had great problems with and voted against the validation and that is why this subsection gives us some problems. However, I thank you for the explanation that this was in accord with what we passed last time. The Democrats and, I presume, the Greens would prefer the amendment which we moved and which was defeated on Friday, but I give an indication that we will vote for this as a very much second-best option.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—The problem with this amendment is not that we did or did not vote for it last time. In fact, I am aware of the fact that not only did we vote for it last time, but we helped to put it. The reason we were convinced to vote for this version amongst the various versions last time was that the legal advice we were given at the time indicated that it was a stronger Racial Discrimination Act amendment than has subsequently proven to be the case. The legal advice at the time—and we all know what kind of pressure cooker situation we were in at the end of last year—was that it was an amendment which would subject the bill to the Racial Discrimination Act. The problem with the reading of the bill—and Senator Bolkus knows this very well, although he says that it is a whole measure—is that the Racial Discrimination Act is only taken into consideration when there is any doubt, and that means it is taken as an interpretive tool. In all the advice we have received, that seems to be the growing consensus.
The government know this. I guess we will all be looking very carefully to see what the government do in relation to this, but they have the same access to legal advice as all the rest of us. They have seen the advice that Senator Harradine has been given. They have seen the advice that we have tabled from Professor Tony Blackshield and they have 
 their own legal advisers. So the government know that the amendment which is being re-put with the addition from Senator Bolkus is not going to save this legislation from racial discrimination.
If I were unkind, I would read out the various quotes from Senator Bolkus at the end of last year where he mentioned that a whole range of people indicated that this bill was racially discriminatory. Of course we know that. We also know that, if there is quite clearly racially discriminatory elements of the bill, elements that do not need to be interpreted, then they will remain racially discriminatory and there is really not a lot we can guarantee the High Court will do.
In fact, we believe this is a false premise. We have had a rotten bill put together and, let us face it, that is what we are talking about. The bill that is left, the bill as we see it, the bill that we are debating, is what is left from the decimated rights of indigenous Australians. It is a rotten bill, it is a discriminatory bill. We believe it is the wrong thing to do to get a rotten bill, stick a Racial Discrimination Act amendment in it and then say, `That's fine. We've done our bit for Aboriginal people.' It is exactly what happened during the Hindmarsh legislation, and we know exactly what protection that afforded the Ngarrindjeri women.
Therefore, I would say to the ALP that it is not good enough. They know that, we know that, the advice from Senator Harradine would indicate that he knows it, too, and the government know it, too. This is not a clause-buster. It will make very little difference to the government's bill, except where there is interpretation needed. The fact that it was voted for last year was simply that, in the pressure cooker at the time, we received advice that has proven not to be accurate.

name: Minchin, Sen Nick
text:
—I think I put last Friday the government's reasons for opposing all the proposed amendments on the Racial Discrimination Act. Our position has not changed since this matter was debated last December. The only difference in the proposition being put before us now from that which 
 was put last December is the addition of the note, which I guess purports to try to limit the operation of the provision but, regrettably, the substantive part of the clause has not changed. It still reads that this act is intended to be read and construed subject to the provisions of the RDA. The only exception is the validation regime. From the government's point of view, that still leaves the degree of considerable legal uncertainty which motivated the previous Keating Labor government to consider and reject the inclusion of such a provision in the original Native Title Act. As I said, a particular provision was inserted in that act which we have retained in the Native Title Amendment Bill.
I refer senators to what Father Frank Brennan has been saying and indeed what he said in today's Australian on this matter. It hardly needs to be said that Father Frank Brennan is a great supporter of the Aboriginal position on this issue,  not the government's. As he said today in the Australian:
Since Wik, people have confused the two issues of non-discrimination and making the new law "subject to the RDA". It is essential that any law be as non-discriminatory and certain as possible. Now there is a new RDA problem: any legislative regime implementing Wik has to accommodate prevailing pastoralists' rights over yielding native title rights.
Such a regime cannot be rendered subject to the RDA because the RDA ensures that all rights are treated the same. If the Aboriginal and government lawyers can come up with a Solomon-like compromise on the RDA, well and good. Otherwise the Senate should leave it well alone.
I think Father Brennan has identified the considerable problems just in one area alone—that is, accommodating the High Court's decision, which we are doing in this bill. The High Court said that, where native title rights have survived and they run into the operation of the pastoralists' rights, then, as a matter of common law, the rights of the pastoralists shall prevail. Why this area is difficult is that not only are we dealing with the interaction of laws that for the first time really involve a property right that is inherently only available to people of a particular race, but that right is founded in the common law, which is, as a fundamental part of our 
 legal system, always subject to statutory rights.
As you would know, democratically elected parliaments make statutory law and courts make common law, and statutory law will always prevail in any circumstances. Here we have a situation where the common law right is available only to people of a particular race and, therefore, not surprisingly, the High Court has said that, where there is any clash, the statutory rights prevail. In many cases, as we know, the statutory rights are held by Aboriginal pastoralists. There are Aboriginal pastoralists who exercise these statutory rights and, where their statutory rights conflict with the surviving native title rights, their statutory rights must prevail, as a matter of law, as declared by the High Court.
Therefore, in the words of Frank Brennan, it is impossible to impose this sort of provision. The Labor Party's wording still leaves it open to someone to propose that each and every provision of the Native Title Act be read and construed subject to provisions of the Racial Discrimination Act. It does not eliminate that possibility. We do not believe the note, of itself, is a sufficient limitation on the potential operation of this clause.
We have to remember that we are talking about a Native Title Act which, as I said before, is probably the most significant federal imposition on land law and land management in this country. It means that virtually every major development on 79 per cent of Australia must comply with that act. If everything done potentially under the Native Title Act is subject to being subsequently challenged by a litigant claiming that there is some inconsistency with the RDA, it would be a legal nightmare, for the reasons most eloquently put by Senator Harradine before lunch in a previous debate.
This is a proposition, as I say, the Senate considered in 1993 and rejected because of the potential legal implications—the legal chaos that could result, the legal uncertainty over thousands and thousands of titles issued under this act and the potential nightmare of every provision being challenged. We maintain that the act, as amended, will continue to be beneficial to Aboriginal people. If there is 
 a view that that is not the case, then of course that can be challenged in the High Court and the High Court can decide whether there is any infringement of the races power. But it is simply unworkable and unacceptable and producing of enormous uncertainty to subject the Native Title Act to the provisions of the Racial Discrimination Act.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text: —Just briefly, the minister seems to have forgotten that something seems to have been missed out here—that is, the certainty for Aboriginal people that they will not be discriminated against and they will not lose their rights. That uncertainty does not seem to have been factored into the consideration.

name: Harradine, Sen Brian
text:
—The issue of the RDA amendment being incorporated into the native title amendment legislation is one of great symbolic significance to the Aboriginal peoples—the indigenous peoples of Australia. That has influenced me greatly in my consideration of this particular matter.
First of all, I suggest to the minister that, far from creating uncertainty, the way the opposition's amendment is now framed is going to give you considerably more certainty than otherwise. Surely it is not considered that proposed section 7(1) is ambiguous because it speaks of the Native Title Act being `read and construed subject to the provisions of the RDA'? It does not say the Native Title Act is `subject to the RDA'. That is a matter of which the government should take full consideration. Presumably it would be much more uncertain if it said that the Native Title Act is `subject to the RDA', but it says that the Native Title Act is to be `read and construed subject to the provisions of the RDA'.
If the government's argument is that proposed section 7(1) is ambiguous, the ambiguity can be removed by a statement of the parliament in a manner which will give effective guidance to the interpretation of the law by the courts. This is precisely what the opposition's amendment does. It takes note 301 from the High Court in Western Australia v. The Commonwealth and incorporates it 
 into the legislation. The actual note before us says:
The provisions of the Racial Discrimination Act 1975  apply to the performance of functions and exercise of powers conferred by or authorised by this Act.
I would have thought that that ought to have gone into the legislation as a substantive clause in any event, and I would not have thought the government would have any objection to that first sentence of the note. The second sentence is, as I noted, from WA v. The Commonwealth, footnote 301, and says:
To construe this Act, and thereby to determine its operation, ambiguous terms should be construed consistently with the Racial Discrimination Act 1975  if that construction would remove ambiguity.
Of course, that is not a clause-busting provision. It is all very right and glib to say that we need a clause-busting provision so as to bust clauses that are racially discriminatory, but that does not even go near facing up to the facts and also the need to have a degree of certainty.
I showed two honourable senators a copy of this document on Friday—if we can remember back that far—which is a six-page document which would probably get into two pages in the Hansard. It is headed: `Notes concerning the RDA amendment'. Rather than take the time of the committee, I seek leave to incorporate those notes into Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
Notes concerning the RDA Amendment
Introduction
One of the most publicised aspects of the Senate debate on the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 concerned the amendment of s 7(1) of the Native Title Act 1993 dealing with the relationship between the Native Title Act and the Racial Discrimination Act 1975.1 During the debate on the amendment on Friday, 5 December 1997, Senator Harradine indicated before the luncheon adjournment that he would oppose the amendment. On the resumption, however, the Senator informed the Senate that he had changed his mind and that he now proposed to support the amendment.2 As a result of Senator Harradine's vote, the amendment was passed by the Senate. 

In the House of Representatives on Saturday, 6 December 1997, the Prime Minister identified the Senate's amendment of s 7(1) as one of the four reasons for the Government's decision to reject the Bill as amended by the Senate. He said, "The third of the proposals which we reject is the proposal to subject the Native Title Act to the provisions of the Racial Discrimination Act."3 However, a detailed consideration of the amendment, indicates that the Government, by so characterising the proposal, has misunderstood the effect of the Senate's RDA amendment and that there is no technical legal justification for the Government's rejection of it.
History of s 7 of the Native Title Act
Before considering the Senate's amendment of s 7, it is worthwhile reviewing the history of the section. It was enacted in the 1993 Act in the following terms:
Racial Discrimination Act
Operation of the RDA not affected
	 7.(1) Nothing in this Act affects the operation of the Racial Discrimination Act 1975.
Validation provisions not affected
	 (2) Subsection (1) does not affect the validation of past acts by or in accordance with this Act.
That provision was included in the Act as the result of an amendment to the Native Title Bill 1993 when it was debated in the Senate in December 1993. The amendment (Green amendment No. 1A inserting a new clause 6A) was moved by the Greens and supported by the then Government as well as the Democrats and Senator Harradine. The wording of the provision was a compromise reached by the Government, the Democrats and the Greens in order to minimise the uncertainty which the Government feared might flow from a provision which subjected the whole of the Native Title Act to the Racial Discrimination Act 1975. Senator Gareth Evans acknowledged this point in the debate:
The concern was that if we overemphasised the specific need for continued consistency with the RDA, perhaps [the legislation's being a special measure under s. 8 of the Racial Discrimination Act 1975] might somehow be put at risk, or other unforeseen consequences may arise. . . . [The provision] makes clear that the Racial Discrimination Act will apply to the provisions of this act and conduct carried out under it. . . . There has never been any doubt about our good faith in wanting the RDA to apply. We have just been concerned about possible unforeseen technical consequences flowing from its application. I think those concerns are met by this drafting.4 

Senator Alston questioned Senator Evans on whether the amendment might itself have unforeseen consequences. He referred by way of example to a number of provisions in the Bill including one preserving public access to beaches. (This provision is to be found in s 212(2) of the Act). Senator Evans replied:
As to the other specific matter that Senator Alston raised on the question of access to beaches, there is I suppose a question mark which does still exist in one's mind. . . . It is not inconceivable that that [provision] might possibly be construed as being a discriminatory act against Aboriginal people in breach of the RDA.
If that is a problem then the parliament will just have to deal with that when it arises in an explicit way. . . . Having regard to, but not being determined in our response by, the advocacy of Aboriginal groups, our belief is that the risk factors, if you like, associated with having a clause like this are not so great as to outweigh the utility of having a clear and resounding demonstration in the body of the legislation itself, not just the preamble, that we really do value the RDA and want to give it effective operation.5
Prior to the enactment of the Native Title Act, the Western Australian parliament had passed its own legislation purporting to establish an alternative native title regime to that proposed in the Commonwealth legislation.6 Under the WA legislation common law native title was extinguished and replaced with statutory rights of traditional usage within a regime prescribed by the Act. After the enactment of the Native Title Act, the WA Government commenced proceedings in the High Court which, inter alia, challenged the validity of the Native Title Act and various substantive provisions thereof.7 This was an important part of WA's case as s 11 of the Native Title Act (which applied to State legislation passed on or after 1 July 1993) provided that native title was not able to be extinguished contrary to the Act. By virtue of s 109 of the Constitution inconsistent WA legislation would have no valid operation.
In the course of the case, the WA Government argued that s 7(1) was destructive of the substantive provisions of the Native Title Act. The submission was summarised by the joint judgment of Mason CJ, Brennan, Deane, Toohey, Gaudron and McHugh JJ as follows:
The Native Title Act was said to discriminate in favour of Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders and thus to offend the Racial Discrimination Act. As s 7(1) preserved the operation of the Racial Discrimination Act, so the argument ran, the offending provisions of the Native Title Act "must be regarded as inoperative".8 The High Court dismissed the submission. The joint judgment said 
 that the argument encountered considerable obstacles and gave three reasons, the effect of which may be summarised as follows:
1. It is not easy to detect any inconsistency between the Native Title Act and the Racial Discrimination Act.
2.	 If there were any discrepancy in the operation of the two Acts, the Native Title Act can be regarded either as a special measure under s 8 of the Racial Discrimination Act or as a law which, though it makes racial distinctions, is not racially discriminatory so as to offend the Racial Discrimination Act or the International Covenant on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination.
3.	 Even if the Native Title Act contains provisions inconsistent with the Racial Discrimination Act 1975 both Acts must be construed so as to avoid absurdity and to give to each of the provisions a scope for operation.9
The joint judgment then stated that the only manner in which the Native Title Act could be construed as affecting the operation of the Racial Discrimination Act 1975 was in the application of the ordinary rule of construction that the general provisions of an earlier Act must yield to the specific provisions of a later Act. The judges concluded:
Section 7(1) provides no basis for interpreting the Native Title Act as subject to the Racial Discrimination	  Act. The Native Title Act prescribes specific rules governing the adjustment of rights and obligations over land subject to native title and s 7(1) cannot be construed as intending to nullify those provisions. It may be that s 7(2) is otiose but that provision is properly to be seen as inserted out of an abundance of caution. It follows that the inconsistency between the WA Act and the Racial Discrimination Act either survived enactment of the Native Title Act or, if the Native Title Act affected the relevant provisions of the Racial Discrimination Act, from the time when that occurred, an inconsistency arose between the WA Act and s 11 of the Native Title Act.10
In other words the High Court was quite explicit that s 7(1) did not nullify the substantive provisions of the Native Title Act as argued by WA. However, as regards the effect of the subsection, the High Court did not make a definitive finding. Earlier in the judgment the judges said, "It is difficult to identify the legal purpose which this provision is intended to serve."11 And earlier still they said in a footnote:
Although nothing in the Native Title Act affects the operation of the Racial Discrimination Act, nothing in the Racial Discrimination Act is capable of affecting the operation of the Native Title Act properly construed. However, to 
 construe the Native Title Act and thereby to determine its operation, ambiguous terms should be construed consistently with the Racial Discrimination Act if that construction would remove ambiguity 12
In the context of the case before it, the High Court did not need to resolve the difficulty in identifying the legal purpose which s 7(1) was intended to serve. The WA legislation was inconsistent with both the Racial Discrimination Act and the Native Title Act. Therefore, if, in accordance with the normal rules of construction, the general provisions of the Racial Discrimination Act must yield to the specific provisions of the Native Title Act, then the WA legislation was inconsistent with s 11 of the Native Title Act. If, however, by operation of s 7(1) the general provisions of the Racial Discrimination Act did not yield, then the WA legislation was inconsistent with that Act.
The uncertainty which the High Court's reasoning exposed as to the legal efficacy of s 7(1) still exists and will continue to exist until the parliament amends the provision or the High Court in a suitable case decides the issue.
Senate Debate on the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997
Despite this uncertainty and the High Court's criticism of s 7(1), the Government in its Bill did not seek to amend the provision. Only s 7(2) was to be amended to include reference to intermediate period acts in the exclusion provisions of that subsection.
The Opposition, in its extensive list of amendments released shortly prior to the Senate debate did not seek to amend s 7(1) either. Rather it proposed to amend the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 by adding to the operative part of the Bill a new section containing an express declaration of the intention of parliament that the provisions of the Racial Discrimination Act are to prevail over the provisions of the amending Act. That proposed amendment has been criticised by the Government and others for going the extra distance which Senator Evans in 1993 had indicated the Opposition, when they were in government, were not prepared to go. But more fundamentally, it applied only to the amending Act. In other words, when reading the Native Title Act as amended by the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997, one would have to be alert to what sections were in the original Act and what sections had been inserted or amended by the amending Act. The uncertainty identified by Senator Evans in 1993 was liable to be compounded by the form of the proposed amendment.
By the time the Opposition amendment came to be moved in the Senate, however, further consideration had been given to the matter and the amendment had been considerably refined. Rather than adding 
 a separate section, the amendment as moved altered the wording of the existing s 7(1) to read:
(1) This Act is intended to be read and construed subject to the provisions of the Racial Discrimination Act 1975.
This is a substantially different provision to that which had originally been proposed by the Opposition. However, the Government does not seem to have comprehended the difference. In the debate Senator Minchin said, "Could I just forewarn Senator Bolkus that I would not mind his explaining this quite innocent question: what is the difference in the wording between the original ALP amendment on this issue and the new amendment?"13 Without waiting for an answer to his question, Senator Minchin continued his speech. It is apparent from this speech that the Senator was in fact still focusing on the vices demonstrated by the original amendment. He criticised the Opposition for proposing something that they were not prepared to contemplate in 1993 and he used such words as "To make the Bill subject to the RDA will have exactly the consequences which . . . Senator Evans forecast, and therefore it is unacceptable."14
Similarly, Senator Harradine seems to have been of the view that the amendment as moved was in substance no different from the original Opposition amendment. In his pre-lunch speech he stressed the uncertainty issue:
I am saying that this measure we have before us today is really a huge invitation to constant, endless litigation. It is not going to do anybody any good. If that is the outcome of placing the RDA provision that has been moved by Senator Bolkus into this legislation, it certainly will create widespread uncertainty, which we do not wish to have. . . . In putting the RDA provision in here, you want a lawyers picnic. You do not want to have a degree of certainty. You are inviting the government to say, `This measure is totally unworkable'. . . . It is unworkable because every provision in the legislation will have to be subject to the RDA. There will be endless litigation about it.
Why did we not put it in the 1993 legislation? For the very reason that we ought not be putting it in here. The Labor government at that time knew that it was a nonsense to put a similar provision in the Native Title Act.15
In his post-lunch speech it is apparent that the Senator more fully appreciated the distinction between the original Opposition amendment and the amendment as moved. Focusing on the words of the amendment, as well as the important political significance of the issue itself, he said:
I am coming to the view that, unless we do what is being proposed—that is, to have the bill read 
 and construed subject to the provisions of the RDA—we may be sending the wrong messages to the whole of Australia and to all Australians . . . .
I feel that it would be unwise for the government to maintain the view that it would be unworkable. The view that I had come to was that the government would regard it as totally unworkable if the RDA provisions went in. I hope the government will see that, in the end, it is probably better to have the RDA provisions there. We tried it in 1993 in subsection 7(1) . . . . As has been expressed around the chamber, subsection 7(1) of the RDA [sic] was found by the High Court to be less than operable. That is the message that has been given to us by the High Court. Perhaps we ought to heed that message and include what is being proposed by the opposition in this bill. Otherwise you could have efforts by some people to overturn this measure by stating that the measure is not constitutional under the race power.16
Why the Government can and should accept the Senate's RDA amendment
The Senator's speech encapsulates the elements which justify the amendment as moved and ultimately adopted by the Senate:
1.	 It is a response to the High Court's criticism of the existing provision.
The Court did not have to decide the legal effect of the provision because the WA legislation was held to be inconsistent with both the Racial Discrimination Act and the Native Title Act. However, the Court did indicate that, if the provision had any meaning at all, then it was limited to altering the ordinary rule of construction applying to inconsistent statutes. The Senate amendment confirms that that is indeed the legal effect which is to be given to the provision. Were s 7(1) to remain unamended then ultimately the High Court would have to decide if the provision had any efficacy. Until such a case were heard and determined there would be uncertainty in this regard. What the Senate has done is to remove that uncertainty and to make clear how the legislature wants the provision construed rather than leaving it up to the High Court to make the decision for it.
2.	 It re-enacts what the parliament agreed to do in 1993
Contrary to what Senator Minchin, in the hurly burly of the debate, may have thought the effect of the amendment to be, it should now be seen, in the light of considered analysis, that it does not do that which the Prime Minister asserted in his speech to the House on 6 December 1997. The amendment does not say, "This Act is subject to the provisions of the Racial Discrimi 
 nation Act 1975". Rather, it comprehends the construction issue identified by the High Court in footnote 301 and in the third of its reasons for rejecting the submission of the WA government on the effect of s 7(1). In that regard it should be noted that the High Court said that "Section 7(1) provides no basis for interpreting the Native Title Act as subject to the Racial Discrimination Act "17
3.	 It would be unwise for the Government to maintain the view that it would be unworkable.
The High Court said that s 7(1) does not nullify the specific provisions of the Native Title Act. To reinforce that point the judges said that s 7(2) may be otiose and "is properly to be seen as inserted out of an abundance of caution."18 Section 7(1), in its original or amended form, so construed does not provide a firm foundation for a challenge to specific provisions of the Native Title Act such as those relating to past acts, future acts, or, in terms of the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997, confirmation of past extinguishment.
4.	 Failure to respond to the High Court's criticism of s 7(1) would send the wrong message to Australia and to all Australians.
The High Court having expressed doubt as to the efficacy of s 7(1), the issue then becomes whether the parliament considers it sufficiently important for it to amend the provision so as to remove the doubt. By failing to act, the parliament will indicate that it no longer considers an effective RDA provision to be worth worrying about and that it is prepared to let the High Court decide whether the relationship is to have any efficacy..
5.	 The presence in the Act of an effective s 7(1) enhances the prospects that the Native Title Act as amended by the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 will be held to be constitutionally valid as being within the races power (s 51 (xxvi) of the Constitution). The Government has consistently maintained that its Bill is not racially discriminatory. Many critics have rejected that assertion and have contended that because the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 does (and the Native Title Act as amended by the Bill will) racially discriminate against the indigenous people of Australia, it will be found by the High Court to be invalid. That view depends on the High Court's holding that the races power requires legislation to be beneficial. This is an issue which is yet to be resolved. If there is such a requirement, then the presence in the legislation of an effective provision relating to the Racial Discrimination Act will provide additional scope for the Government to argue that 
 the Bill and the amended Act, on balance, are beneficial and/or a special measure.
Conclusion
If the Government were to agree to the Senate's RDA amendment, there would be less—not more—uncertainty than exists under the present legislation. The issue of access to the beaches, for example, remains whether the parliament adopts the original s 7(1) or the amended form. But that is not a problem created by the Senate amendment of December 1997. The parliament in 1993 indicated when it enacted the Greens amendment No. 1A that it was prepared to accept the risk in that regard. Four years later we still do not know whether the risk is real or not. (But the High Court's comments on the limited effect of s 7 suggest that it is not real.) However, we do know that by leaving s 7(1) in its unamended form the uncertainty as to the efficacy of s 7(1), identified by the High Court in 1995, will remain until the High Court, rather than the parliament, decides the issue.

—I thank the committee. I would point out to the Senate and re-emphasise a number of points in the notes as to why the government can and should accept the Senate's RDA amendment: first of all, because it is a response to the High Court criticisms of the existing provisions, and it is the situations that have given rise to those criticisms by the High Court that have concerned the government. The High Court did not have to decide the legal effect of provisions because the WA legislation was held to be inconsistent with the RDA, and also with the Native Title Act. But the court indicated that, if the provision had any meaning at all, then it was limited to altering the ordinary rule of construction applied to inconsistent statutes. The Senate amendments confirm that that is indeed the legal effect which is to be given to the provision.
Secondly, the RDA amendment actually re-enacts what parliament agreed to do in 1993 and I have to point out that I have often wondered why the government was so concerned about this particular matter. I fear that the government may have thought that the effect of the amendment was that it should be now seen, in the light of considered analysis, that it does not do what was suggested by the government the last time we met. The Prime Minister asserted in his speech on 6 November, and this is very important—it is worth while reading the Prime Minister's comments—that, because of the RDA amendment, the act would be subject to the provisions of the Racial Discrimination Act 1975.
In fact, as I have just indicated, that is not the situation at all on this particular measure. We are saying that the provision means that it is to be read and construed subject to the RDA. It does not say that the Native Title Act is subject to the RDA. Now, of course, it is made even more certain because the opposition is suggesting, and I am supporting it, that it comprehends the construction issue identified in the High Court's footnote of 301 in the third of its reasons for rejecting the submission of the WA government on the effect of section 7(1). In that regard it should be noted that the High Court said:
Section 7.(1) provides no basis for interpreting the Native Title Act as subject to the Racial Discrimination Act.
That is something that account should be taken of by the whole of the committee, including the government. The third point that I make is that it would be unwise for the government to maintain the view that the provisions that we are suggesting would be unworkable. The point is that the High Court said that section 7(1) does not nullify the specific provisions of the Native Title Act. To reinforce that point, the judges said that section 7(2) is:
. . . properly to be seen as inserted out of an abundance of caution. Section 7.(1) in its original or amended form, so construed, does not provide a firm foundation for a challenge to specific provisions of the Native Title Act, such as those relating to past acts, future acts, or in terms of the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997, confirmation of past extinguishment.
Again, the fourth point that I am putting to the government is that failure to respond to the High Court's criticism of section 7(1) would send the wrong message to Australia and to all Australians. The fifth point is that the presence in the Act of an effective section 7(1) enhances the prospect that the Native Title Act, as amended by the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 [No. 2] , will be held to be constitutionally valid, as being within the races power of section 51(xxvi) of the constitution.
The government has consistently maintained that its bill is not racially discriminatory. Many critics have actually rejected that assertion and have contended that because the  Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 [No. 2]  does, and the Native Title Act, as amended by that bill, will, racially discriminate against the indigenous people of Australia, it will be found by the High Court to be invalid. That view depends on the High Court's holding that the races power requires legislation to be beneficial and, despite what happened in the Hindmarsh Island decision, you would be a very brave person to bet which way the High Court might ultimately fall in regard to that particular matter.
—True, very true.
—Thanks, Senator Woodley. This is an issue which is, despite what has happened in the Hindmarsh Island case or because of what was said in the Hindmarsh Island case by a number of the judges, yet to be resolved. If there is such a requirement, then the presence in the legislation of an effective provision relating to racial discrimination will provide additional scope to the government to argue that the bill and the amended act, on balance, are beneficial and/or a special measure.
I think the amendment moved by Senator Bolkus for the opposition should be embraced at this time by the government. There has been a fear that it would be a clause busting provision. The Senate deliberately voted against such proposals on Friday. I believe this particular provision put forward by the opposition should be supported by the committee and I believe it ought to be supported by the government as well.

name: Woodley, Sen John
text: —I want to ask the minister a question. I listened to his speech and I think it is important that I ask this question in terms of the vote we are about to take. Minister, I understand that the whole issue of the Racial Discrimination Act applying to the Native Title Amendment Bill is one of the government's sticking points. Are you saying that—and I think this is helpful to us if I can ask you this question—this really would be one of those points at which the government could not accept such an amendment and would, as far as you are concerned, strike down the bill if we pass this amendment?

name: Minchin, Sen Nick
text:
—The government has stated repeatedly that the four critical sticking points with the Senate amendments are the Racial Discrimination Act, the registration test, the right to negotiate and the sunset clause. Amendments of that kind were rejected by the government in the House of Representatives in December. Nothing in this amendment of the Labor Party has so altered the intent of the Senate's amendment in such a way as to suggest that the government could do anything other than reject this amendment.
 It remains a critical provision for us because of the enormous impact of the Native Title Act on Australia. Now,  following the Wik decision, the amended act will affect every single exploration and mining lease and major development on 79 per cent of Australia. That is where all that sort of activity occurs anyway, so we are talking about everything in Australia being affected by the Native Title Act as amended. We simply are of the view, on balance, that to subject the act to the provisions of the Racial Discrimination Act would render the practical workability of the Native Title Act so uncertain for the billions and billions of dollars of activity that occurs every year in Australia as to make this an unacceptable proposition.
 Thousands of people every day decide whether they are going to invest their money, seek licences, seek leases or engage in developments that create jobs and create wealth. They have to go through all the state provisions to achieve what they want to do. Then there is another layer to go through of everything to do with the Native Title Act. Any responsible lawyer advising any major developer is going to say, `Yes, we think that, if you do all this, you'll comply with the state things. If you do all this, we think you'll comply with the Native Title Act, but of course I've got to tell you that, in terms of your investors, your shareholders, your lenders and everybody else, there is always the possibility of someone challenging what you are doing in your investment and your lease, even if you've got it validly under the NTA, as somehow invalidly issued because of the operation of the RDA.'
They may not have a case, but for a developer who is risking shareholders' funds of, as we know with Century,  a billion dollars or whatever, you have to look at the risks. If there is a risk that the lease upon which your whole investment depends could be held up in court for who knows how long even though you have passed all the steps along the way and got it validly issued under the Native Title Act—which of course is not an easy process—but, because of some asserted problem resulting from the fact that the act is intended to be read and construed subject to 
 the provisions of the Racial Discrimination Act, it will have, in our view, potentially devastating consequences.
 To pick up on what Senator Harradine said, he is seeking to assure us that the words `to be read and construed subject to the RDA' are different from saying `subject to the RDA'. He may be right, but he may be completely wrong. I can guarantee you that, if you were to pass this and we were to accept it, there will be a legal argument put that, in practice, there is really no difference and that the act should be seen as subject to the RDA. That will be an argument that would be put—who knows what a court might find? Who knows then whether we are going to be in a situation where every provision of the NTA is to be examined subject to the provision of the RDA or whether everything done under the NTA is subject to challenge as being somehow inconsistent with the RDA.
I have to say no-one in here has yet given me an answer to the very problem identified by Father Brennan—that we are now dealing with native title having survived on pastoral leases, an issue that the Senate did not have in its mind when it passed the Native Title Act. We now have a situation where the High Court has said there is a hierarchy of rights on pastoral leases, which is totally inconsistent with the whole notion of the RDA that you have equal rights.
From the other point of view, you also have to acknowledge and remember that the right to negotiate is a procedural right available only to a certain group of people, not to any other titleholders. It is arguable—and the argument is put—that it is a discriminatory right. If you start imposing these sorts of double jeopardy propositions, in our view you do enormous damage to the certainty that is required of the law, particularly in an area like property law where the certainty that is required is fundamental to the prosperity of the whole nation. The very issue that we are all concerned about—the workability of the Native Title Act—is dramatically affected potentially by the operation of this provision.

name: Brown, Sen Bob
text:
—In a way what Senator Minchin says corroborates the point of view that we have been 
 taking here. There needs to be clarity and there needs to be certainty. We should not be leaving it to the High Court to sort this out. Sadly, that is what this weak, middle of the road provision does. It does not give that clarity and certainty that Senator Harradine is calling for and it is not properly responding to the High Court when it says that a clear message should be given to the people of Australia about that.
I submit we are in here to ensure that we do not discriminate against the indigenous people of this country wholesale through this legislation. I submit this legislation does just that and a lot of other people think the same, not least the indigenous people in this country. But if it does not and the government is right in what it says, it ought to have had no trouble accepting any amendment which empowered the High Court to look at it.
Talk about double jeopardy. The fact is there is double talk on the other side of the chamber when it comes to this provision. Senator Minchin says that it will affect every single development on 79 per cent of Australia. What about the indigenous interests there? He is saying that indigenous interests in their land, in their traditional rights and in their culture being given integrity are going to be serially dented, eroded and affected by this panoply of developments that he foresees across 79 per cent of Australia. We can argue with that one, but that is the one that the Prime Minister brought forward.
`They should have no protection if it discriminates against them'—that is what is being said here. The government does not want the indigenous people of this country to be protected when it moves to back those who would develop the country in a way which is inimical to their rights and interests. It is more than that. This is cutting the ground from under the indigenous people's rights to have even a say. Let us remember that.
These developments are not just mines; they are dams, cotton crops, broad scale plantations, potential woodchip operations, deep sea fisheries, oil drillings, roads, canals and fences. There are huge changes to northern Australia coming up. The government is saying, `We are not going to give the indigen 
 ous people a right to a say even in what happens'—no negotiating rights. That of itself would be bad enough, but Senator Harradine and the Labor Party are saying, `Ditto: the indigenous people get no say in the transformation of their country that is coming up.'
The government is saying, `Let's not have the Racial Discrimination Act surveying this loss of rights to the indigenous people.' Labor and Senator Harradine are saying, `Let's have some weak, middle of the road provision'—as it turns out to be; we thought it was strong last December and we find out now it is not, as Senator Margetts has pointed out—`which will leave it to the High Court. But we hope it will tie the High Court's hands in a way that it is not going to get down to any specific clauses in this legislation which may be racially discriminatory.'
The best the High Court can do is weigh up all the discrimination with the benefits and, if on balance it is satisfied that it is not too bad for the Aboriginal people, then the discrimination stands. There is to be no clause busting here; discriminatory clauses which specifically discriminate against the indigenous people of this country stand. That is what is being put to the Senate. That is why we oppose it.
As Senator Woodley said, the Labor Party, Senator Harradine and the government having failed the test on this issue now leave us in the position where we support the weak fall-back provision, the one we thought was strong last December. The problem with that is that this is going to be revisited not just on us but on this community for a long time to come. You cannot discriminate against people through legislation and get away with it. You cannot divest yourself of the responsibility as legislators to leave it to the courts to sort it out.
Senator Harradine says we should have clarity here. The clarity was in Senator Margetts's amendment and the amendment I moved this morning, both of which he opposed. They said to the High Court, `Discrimination in this legislation will be removed.' That is what our amendments said. Senator Harradine voted that down. The Labor Party voted that down. The government voted that down.
So the best we get is, `Put it back to the High Court without clarity and hope it will come up with a resolution.' That is not strong or courageous legislating. That is, at best, ducking the issue. I submit that there will be people voting for this legislation who will be hoping it has no effect, taking into account the Brennan theory that the problems coming out of it are too much for us to face up to. I submit that, given our history, it is about time we did take a stand. That might cause the community a little bit of difficulty. But at least we should face up to reversing the troubles that the indigenous people have had in the past and making sure that we do not compound them into the future.
The final thing I want to say—and I do not want to allow this to pass—is that I challenged the Labor Party, I challenged Senator Harradine, and I challenged the government to get up and say why they did not support the clear indiction to the High Court not to allow racial discrimination; and why they do not support busting clauses which are discriminatory. Not one of them got to their feet. I am not allowed to call that cowardly but I submit that that is what it is. I submit that it is ducking their responsibility to answer for what they are doing. I submit that it is failing to have the gumption to get up here and defend the indefensible. Their silence speaks volumes. Their absence of response speaks volumes about what is happening here and they ought to think about that.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—The minister has indicated that nothing has changed since last year. They have made very strong statements, apparently, with regard to what they want and do not want out of this debate about dispossession at the margins. I am wondering if this means that we can all go home now. The government has said they are going to take their toys and go home and that means there is absolutely no point in our continuing on this debate. Is that, in fact, the case or will the theatre be played out in the lower house when we all know that this amendment does, at best, very little? After a display of hands on hearts and wringing of their hands, we will find that the government has decided after all that their 
 advice might not have been what it was and that this amendment does what we have said—that is, very little.
I notice the minister has gone behind the screens with Senator Bolkus. I do not know whether this is to find another form of words or whether this is to make a new statement which will clarify whether this is game, set and match. Perhaps it means that this is where the debate ends and the rest becomes purely icing on the cake. Perhaps what we should have done, as a Senate, is made sure that the very best amendment went in. It seems that this is largely theatre with the government saying to the audience, `Look, this really is not going to do much so go on, accept it, ` which is what I am hearing. The government is saying, `This really is not going to bust your clauses. This isn't really going to make sure we are not discriminatory in the bill. Come on, let us have it. Let's pretend,' because that is what it is—it is pretence.
What is happening behind the screen now? Do we now have an announcement that we can all go home, that in reality all the rest is just nonsense? Or is the government going to say, `Okay, maybe we were badly advised before and we really are going to accept it'? Or, do we now have a new emanation and people are going to come out with a new decision altogether which is even weaker than the weak amendment we are being asked to accept again?

name: Woodley, Sen John
text:
—I thank the minister for his answer because it did clarify the situation for us very well. I actually thought that Senator Harradine's arguments may have swayed the government because they were very convincing. Let me say again that, although this is certainly not the Democrats preferred option, we will vote for this amendment. It looks to me as if the government is not prepared to shift at all. I might say there has been a lot of talk about compromise, but it has only been one side that has been asked to compromise. The government has not shifted one little bit. I do not know whether they believe the 10-point Wik plan is a compromise. But that compromise was never worked out with 
 anyone except the government and the people it wanted to talk to.
It is quite clear now that the government's refusal to consider the application of what I regard as Australia's primary human rights legislation—that is, the outlawing of racial discrimination—is a real trigger for a race election based on Wik. I wonder whether, reiterating what Senator Margetts said, there is any point in going any further once we do vote on this particular amendment, if it means that that sticking point will be sufficient to strike down this legislation. I asked the question because I wanted to be very clear when I voted what it was I was voting for. It may be that if it is sufficient to strike down the bill—and I thought that was what the minister was saying to us—then perhaps the rest of the debate might need to be adjourned. I do not know. But if this clause is totally unacceptable to the Howard government, then perhaps we are on the way to an election. That is why I was grateful to the minister, even though I disagree with his position, for at least clarifying that no further qualification of the Racial Discrimination Act would be acceptable to the government. If this qualification—which I agree is very much a second best option—is not acceptable to the government, then perhaps we should all go home. I certainly have a lot to do before Easter. Perhaps that statement should be made and then let us see which way the vote goes.

name: Brown, Sen Bob

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text: —Is the minister going to respond to the question about whether or not there is any point in continuing after this vote?

name: Minchin, Sen Nick
text:
—The question suggests that the government would withdraw the bill. The government is not withdrawing the bill. The government has put this bill to the Senate and it wants the Senate to pass the bill in the form presented to the Senate. Obviously, we should and will debate the amendments that have been put and see what form the bill comes out of the Senate in. It will then go to the House of Representatives for the House of Representatives to consider its reaction to the bill. We hope and intend that there will be a full debate on this bill and that we will pass the bill—albeit, as it would appear, with some amendments which the government may not be able to accept in the House of Representatives.
In response to Senator Woodley in relation to the RDA, I can only deal with amendments as presented by other parties to the bill as presented by the government. The amendments presented to the government on the RDA are, for the reasons I have outlined, not able to be supported by the government. I have repeatedly said on behalf of the government that, in relation to the whole bill, we are not in a position to compromise it or reduce its workability but any propositions on any issues which meet government policy, are workable and practical will obviously be considered by us.
The government has put in 99 amendments to this bill which attempt to meet some of the concerns raised by the Senate last time and which meet them in a way that we think clarifies the operation of the act, improves the act, and meets some of the misunderstandings that were raised in the last Senate debate. That is an act of good faith on our part. It shows our reasonableness in the way we wish the bill to be dealt with.
Throughout this debate, we will continue to treat all proposed amendments on their merits and consider them against the criteria—which I am bound to apply as the representative of 
 the government—of whether or not they are consistent with government policy, practical and workable. Amendments put before the government in relation to the RDA do not meet those criteria.

name: Brown, Sen Bob
text: —Just following up on what Senator Margetts had to say: I do not think she asked the minister if the government would withdraw the bill; what she was getting at was whether, if this amendment is passed, the government is still going to entertain accepting the legislation in the House of Representatives or whether it is firm on the position that it has taken consistently in public that an RDA amendment would not be acceptable.

name: Minchin, Sen Nick
text: —I can only repeat government policy. It is a matter for the government in the House of Representatives, but government policy is that the amendments that have been proposed in relation to the Racial Discrimination Act are unacceptable to the government and would be rejected by the House of Representatives. That is the policy. I have no reason to believe that that would change.

name: Woodley, Sen John
text:
—I have just one sentence: I think it is very important that we make clear that this is, in fact, the trigger for a double dissolution that we are voting on, and I do not resile from voting in the way which I have already indicated.
	 Question put:
	 That the amendment (Senator Bolkus's ) be agreed to.

name: Bolkus, Sen Nick
text:
—The issues of threshold tests have become quite relevant here. In this area, as in all the others, the opposition moved quite a number of amendments last time—amendments which presented an alternative approach to the problems here but amendments which, in the main, were not accepted. As reflected in the second reading amendment, our concerns are and continue to be that 
 the government has gone too far and, in going too far, questions arise as to workability, constitutionality and also unfairness.
The starting point for the opposition in this area—and I think this is the position of others in the Senate—is that changes are needed here. There are problems; there are problems in terms of overlapping native title claims. Some claims have been lodged in ambit terms, whilst a small number have been overly optimistic. But our proposals differ from the government's in that our proposals maintain that the government has failed to sufficiently take into account the fundamental cultural relationship between Aborigines and their land. The government's amendments are extremely onerous and in some respects are based on a denial or a winding back of the common law.
Our amendments had a number of major purposes. Specifically, they were geared towards ensuring that claims would not be registered unless they comply with strength in criteria and they are geared towards assigning clear roles for the register, for the rep bodies and for the registration process. We also attempted to make explicit provision for challenges to be made against false claims and applications. Concern has been with respect to overlapping claims. What we tried to do last time was to provide mechanisms for dealing more effectively with overlapping claims on the current register and with claims registered since June 1996.
Our criticism of the government's position is and continues to be that the threshold test in the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 [No. 2]  is complex, is ambiguous in places and extends beyond a reasonable balance. For instance, the government's physical test started out by excluding those who had been locked out of their country. We felt that was totally unjust.
The other injustice we identified was that in the government's provision they were paring back the common law. The government bill has failed to recognised the cultural connection of Aboriginal people to their land. There will be situations where a claimant has not had physical access to the land but still retains the religion, the stories, the knowledge 
 and the traditional law and customs relating to his or her traditional country. We moved an amendment to ensure that that common law right was being protected.
With respect to multiple claims, we felt the government went a bit far. They got the balance wrong. Some overlapping claims can reflect traditional law. Traditional law can accommodate groups having a right to traverse the country of others through soul lines and dreaming tracks. Generally, as I say, we think the government's balance was wrong and we think there was inherent unfairness in their winding back common law rights; not just unfairness, but also there would be constitutionality problems involved in it as well.
Concerning our position, we put up a proposal which ensured that the registrar was, for instance, not to register an application unless satisfied that the certification was reasonably made by the rep body. We ensured review under the AD(JR). We ensured that there was capacity to uncover situations for instance of fraud in an application, and a whole range of mechanisms which were geared towards ensuring that the process could be somewhat more streamlined and made more sustainable.
We also recognise the role of rep bodies—this will be a part of the debate later on. Under the government's proposal, rep bodies would have increased and enhanced roles. We also thought the rep bodies could have a vital role to play, particularly with respect to retrospective reviewing of overlapping claims. We also pursued a provision to ensure that challenges could be made to the Federal Court as to the truth of sworn facts in an application.
Priority considerations were reflected in our legislation through amendments which sought to ensure that the registrar would give priority to consideration of claims in relation to areas over which section 29 notices had been given. It goes on, but at the end of the debate, as I said, most of our amendments were not accepted. But we are now confronted with legislation which we have to tackle in a way in which our objective is to state our previous position and also to see whether we can make 
 some gains on what was passed through the Senate last year.
The core of the debate here will go as to the threshold test, the registration test. The revised amendments go to this and we maintain that the government's balance between procedural rigour and fairness has not been struck properly. Native title applicants will be required to provide detailed information about the factual basis of the claim. We have no problems with that. Non-native title parties will be entitled to challenge factual assertions in the Federal Court and the registrar must only enter onto the register of claims details of claims and interests which, in the opinion of the registrar, can be established prima facie. That amendment also reflects the amendments moved by Labor in the previous proceedings in December last year. However, the revised registration test does not require native title applicants to meet criteria which have a speculative foundation in the common law. In this way, we believe the government goes too far. It excludes from registration people who might have a firm basis in the common law.
We will be moving amendments and I will go to those later during the deliberations in the committee process. I can say at this stage that the government amendments, which I am sure will be moved, are on the whole supported by the opposition, in many instances not because they are the preferred option but because they are incremental gains on the debate last year.
