name: Minchin, Sen Nick
text:
—The government is moving its own amendments to the registration test, Nos 66 to 76, which are a sign, I think, of our good faith and our willingness to consider propositions put to us and matters that arose out of the Senate deliberations last December. We have not watered the test down, because we think a sufficiently rigorous registration test is vital to the effective operation of the Native Title Act and the ending of the real problem we have across Australia of completing overlapping claims which are causing considerable dissent within Aboriginal communities, let alone in the wider community.
In particular, we have considered the misunderstanding about the operation of the prima facie test that was raised in the Senate. There was some fear that every single native title right and interest claimed in any one claim had to pass the prima facie test or the whole claim could not be registered. That was never our intention. To the extent that it could be read as having that effect, we have proposed an amendment to give it the meaning we intended. The amendment says:
The Registrar must consider that, prima facie, at least some of the native title rights and interests claimed in the application can be established.
The note attached to the amendment says that only those rights and interests that are established are taken into account for the purposes of the right to negotiate. That is what was intended. In other words, if one claim contains 10 native title rights and interests which are sought, and six of those pass the registration test, the claim is registered with respect to those six. Those six are then able to be the 
 subject for consideration in the right to negotiate process but not the four for which a prima facie case could not be made. It does not mean that because four of the rights claimed did not meet the test the claim does not get registered, which was, I think, the misunderstanding on the part of some in respect of the previous tests. So I think that is a clarification which I would hope the Senate should accept.
In relation to physical connection, it remains our view that it is not unreasonable to say that for a claim to be registered at least one member of the claim group should have or have had a traditional physical connection to some part of the area claimed. The obverse of that is to say that a claim should be registered even though not one member of the claim group has ever had any physical connection to the land claimed. Remembering that the registration test is about access to all the statutory procedural rights available to registered claimants with respect to future developments, that is not an unreasonable test. To suggest that those significant procedural rights, including the right to negotiate in respect of mining and compulsory acquisitions on 39 per cent of Australia, should be available to claim groups even though not one of them has ever had any connection to the land claimed seems to us—and, I think, to the wider community—a preposterous suggestion.
We have changed the way in which the physical connection test is described, with the addition of 7(b), to make it clear that, where just one member of the claim group had had a connection and would have expected to have continued to have that connection but for things done either by the Crown or a statutory authority or any other person, then that will satisfy the registration test. We believe that is an up-front acknowledgment of what may well have occurred in the past, and that is that some members of claim groups may well have had their connection to that land severed by actions of that kind, and they should not be prejudiced in having their claims registered. This takes account of such a situation, but we do not believe that we can go beyond that to another generation and therefore be in a situation where claims are 
 registered even though not one member of what may be a very big claim group has ever had any physical connection to the land claimed.
This does not affect the rights of claimants to seek native title determinations before the Federal Court by normal Federal Court action. This registration test, I remind you, is about registration with the tribunal essentially for access to the statutory benefits of the right to negotiate. Therefore, a test of this kind is, we think, perfectly fair and reasonable.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—I would like to make a substantial contribution to this issue. I know we are going to be very close to question time, so perhaps I could make some introductory remarks now and expand on them more fully when we reconvene to look at this legislation.
The issue of physical connection test is, to the Greens, one of the most important issues in this bill that we are considering. It is the issue of whether or not the government is willing to accept the spiritual connection that indigenous Australians feel for their land. It is about basic respect and about basic understanding of the culture and spirituality of indigenous Australians who, as I have pointed out, have never ceded sovereignty on their lands.
So we are dealing with what is considered by the Greens to be the most important issue. We have had buckets of extinguishment result from the dealing with the bill so far. At the end of last year, we had buckets and buckets of extinguishment. We are dealing with a situation where we are staring at the possibility of blatant disrespect, and the issue is the ability of indigenous Australians to be respected—the kind of respect that has been discussed in relation to the heritage act with the Justice Evatt report, the kind of issue that has not been taken up by the government.
Whenever even members of the government talk about the issue of indigenous Australians and the land, they acknowledge the spiritual connection. What I want to know is: if that is acknowledged in just about every speech we hear at public places in various ways, why does it stop short of legislative acceptance? I believe that is impossible to answer. There is 
 no reason why. Many people believe we are getting to the point where the government is going to be asking us to make a decision which, in fact, denies that spirituality. That is why this is going be probably the most important issue, in terms of both gesture and reality, to indigenous Australians—that is, whether  or not the spirituality of indigenous Australians is respected.
Progress reported.

name: Parer, Sen Warwick
text:
—Last Thursday, 2 April, Senator Murphy asked me a question in regard to the Anti-Dumping Authority's inquiry into wood-free coated paper from a number of countries. He also asked me a supplementary question. I seek leave to incorporate the detailed answer given to me by the Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs to both the original answer and the supplementary. I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard .
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
Question:
Minister [Parer] can you tell the Senate whether the Minister for Customs will reject the ADA's finding that the amount of paper dumped by Belgium, France, the Netherlands, Switzerland and Taiwan is negligible because, according to the ADA, it constitutes only seven per cent of the total Australian import volume? Will the Government instead commit to imposing anti-dumping duties upon the relevant companies upon the grounds that no level of dumping is acceptable when people's jobs are at risk?
Answer:
This question relates to the Anti-Dumping Authority's Inquiry into woodfree coated paper from a number of countries. The Anti-Dumping Authority announced on 1 April, by Notice published in the Financial Review, that it had terminated the inquiry into coated paper from Belgium, France, the Netherlands, Switzerland and Taiwan as the total volume of exports from these countries was no more than 7 per cent of the total Australian import volume over the period of the period.
Under subsection 7B(3) of the Anti-Dumping Authority Act 1988, the Authority must terminate an inquiry if it finds that dumped exports from a particular country represent less than three per cent of total imports of the goods under inquiry or if exports from countries, whose individual share of imports are less than three per cent, when combined are seven per cent or less. 

The Authority has found that dumped imports of coated paper from Belgium, France, the Netherlands, Switzerland and Taiwan, when combined, represent no more than seven per cent of total imports. In fact, they only represent about three per cent, which equates to some two per cent of the Australian market.
If the Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs were to act as suggested by Senator Murphy, he would be acting contrary to legislation enacted by this Parliament and contrary to Australia's obligations under the WTO Dumping Agreement. Clearly, in view of both of these points, the Minister should not and cannot so act.
In 1994 Australia, along with many other countries, became a signatory to the WTO Agreements. One such Agreement under the banner of the WTO is The Agreement on Implementation of Article VI of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade 1994—commonly referred to as `the Dumping Agreement'.
Article 5.8 of that Agreement states:
'. . . an inquiry shall be terminated immediately in cases where the authorities determine that the volume of dumped imports. . . is negligible'.
The Agreement goes on to say that, in this context, `negligible' means that the volume of dumped goods from a particular country is less than 3 per cent of total imports of those goods into a Member country or, where several countries have less than 3 per cent of such imports, their combined share does not exceed 7 per cent of imports.
Article 18.4 of the Dumping Agreement requires that signatories shall take all necessary steps to ensure that their domestic laws and regulations conform with the provisions of the Agreement. In response to this Article the then Government introduced a Bill into this Parliament in 1994 to amend the relevant Acts dealing with anti-dumping matters. The Bill was passed by both Houses and the amended legislation took effect from 1 January 1995.
One such amendment was the introduction of a new section into the Anti-Dumping Authority Act 1988 section 7B. Subsection 7B(3) states that the Anti-Dumping Authority must terminate a dumping inquiry if it finds that the volume of dumped goods is negligible. The definition of `negligible' is to be found in section 269TDA of the Customs Act 1901 but, for practical purposes, is essentially identical to that contained in the Dumping Agreement as explained above.
If the Authority finds that the criteria applying under subsection 7B(3) of its Act apply in a given case, the Parliament has decided that the Authority is to terminate the inquiry with respect to the exporters in question. My advice is that such termination is mandatory (the Authority has no 
 discretion in the matter) and has not issued powers to the Minister to overturn the Authority if it so acts.
Against this background, it is obvious that the Minister cannot overturn a decision by the Authority to terminate an inquiry. If he were to do so, he would clearly be acting contrary to law, contrary to the Dumping Agreement and in contempt of this Parliament.
These were amendments proposed by the then Government, the Labor Party, and if Senator Murphy has a problem with the fact that the Authority must terminate the inquiry then he should ask his colleagues, Senators Schacht and Cook who were the relevant Ministers at the time.
Let me reiterate that the legislation is quite clear and unambiguous on the division of power for terminating inquiries and where the Authority is authorised to terminate, the provisions are mandatory. The Minister has no authority in this matter.
There is another feature of both Australia's legislation and the Dumping Agreement that would prevent the Minister imposing measures on the basis suggested by Senator Murphy. Before the Minister can impose dumping duties on future exports of a particular product, he must be satisfied—in accordance with subsection 269TG(2) of the Customs Act 1901—that dumping has caused or threatens to cause material injury to the Australian industry producing like goods, and that there may be future exports that may be dumped. This requirement has been reflected in Australia's anti-dumping legislation for decades and is also contained in the Dumping Agreement.
There is no scope for the Minister to impose anti-dumping measures on the ground that `no level of dumping is acceptable' as suggested by Senator Murphy. This is not an adequate basis in law, nor in terms of Australia's international obligations, for imposing such measures.
Question
Madam President, I ask- a supplementary question. Minister, I thank you for the part answer that you gave, but you did not really address the question with regards to whether or not the government will reject the ADA findings and impose any duties. I guess that is part of the problem. I wonder whether or not the Minister is going to tell the workers at the Wesley Vale paper mill in Tasmania that the loss of their jobs on the basis of a result of a so-called negligible amount of dumped paper is an acceptable price to pay for the Government's failure to introduce legislation to improve the anti-dumping laws of this country. Is this just not another example of the long list of the non-core promises for which Australians again must pay? 

Answer
On 25 February the Ministers for Industry, Science and Tourism and Customs and Consumer Affairs announced that there would be a comprehensive reform of Australia's anti-dumping and countervailing duty mechanisms. Under the new arrangements, interim duties can be imposed after 60 days, the time taken to reach a final finding will be reduced to 155 days and the Anti-Dumping Authority will be abolished. These reforms will give Australia the fastest anti-dumping arrangements in the world. Draft legislation to implement the new arrangements is expected to be introduced into Parliament in the May budget session with a commencement date of 1 July 1998.

name: Ray, Sen Robert
text:
—I present the 70th report of the Committee of Privileges, entitled Questions arising from proceedings of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority .
Ordered that the report be printed.
—I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.
Leave granted.
—I move:
That the Senate take note of the report.
On 26 June 1997, on the motion of Senator Ferris, the following matter was referred to the Committee of Privileges:
That the questions raised in the letter dated 26 June 1997 from the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority be referred to the Standing Committee of Privileges.
The questions involved the appearance at a public hearing by Mr John Elliott after Mr Elliott had made a written submission relating to an inquiry by the joint committee on the operations of the National Crime Authority. One member of the Committee, Senator Stephen Conroy, sought to question Mr Elliott using as a basis for his questioning a document which was challenged by Mr Elliott's legal adviser as being improperly obtained. As a consequence of the NCA committee discussions, the document from which he quoted 
 was expunged from the Hansard  record of proceedings.
Following the public hearing, the NCA committee raised questions on which it sought what was in effect an advisory opinion from the Senate Committee of Privileges. The questions, in order, asked by the NCA committee and the answers which the Committee of Privileges now gives, are as follows:
(a)	 whether Senator Conroy's rights in relation to his capacity to question a witness appearing before the Committee were infringed in relation to the Committee's proceedings in Melbourne on 12 June 1997.
The answer to that is:
Having concluded that none of the evidence given by Mr John Elliott in his written submission of 4 June 1997, and his oral presentation of 12 June 1997, should have been received by the National Crime Authority Committee (see answers to questions (b) and (c) below), and that as a consequence no members of that committee should have been permitted to question him, the Committee of Privileges must also conclude that Senator Conroy's rights as a member of the committee were not infringed.
The next questions are:
(b)	 whether a member of the Committee is prohibited from asking questions of a witness in respect of evidence given to the Committee by that witness covered by either of the elements of subsection 55(2) of the National Crime Authority Act 1984 or that relates to material covered by section 51 of the Act.
and
(c)	 whether the Committee was prohibited from receiving some or all of the evidence of Mr John Elliott in Melbourne on 12 June 1997, because of the provisions in subsection 55(2) of the National Crime Authority Act 1984, or because the evidence related to material covered by section 51 of the act.
The answer to that is:
The Committee of Privileges has concluded that, given the nature of Mr Elliott's evidence, both written and oral, before the NCA Committee, that committee was so constrained by subsection 55(2) of the National Crime Authority Act 1984 that it was prohibited from receiving any such evidence. It follows that committee members were similarly prohibited from asking questions of him in respect of the proscribed evidence. It also follows that committee members generally are prohibited from either receiving, or asking questions in respect of, evidence given by a witness covered by either of 
 the elements of subsection 55(2) of the National Crime Authority Act 1984.
The committee has further concluded that section 51 of the National Crime Authority Act 1984 had no application to the proceedings of the National Crime Authority Committee on 12 June 1997, and has no general application to that committee's proceedings.
The question under (d) was:
(d)	 whether, as a consequence of the consideration of point (c), some or all of the evidence Mr Elliott gave to the Committee should be expunged from the transcript of evidence.
Our answer to that is:
While this question is ultimately a matter for the NCA Committee to determine, the Committee of Privileges suggests that expungement of any evidence taken by that committee on 12 June 1997 is impracticable, ineffectual and undesirable.
In reaching these conclusions, the Committee of Privileges points to the difficult relationship between the NCA Committee and the National Crime Authority since the act came into operation because of the constraints imposed by section 55(2). It observes that the present NCA Committee might not have faced such difficulties as have led to the present conclusions if recommendations of its predecessor had previously been acted upon.
The Committee of Privileges notes that the NCA Committee has tabled in the House of Representatives and is about to table in this chamber a report on the general terms of reference to which I have referred; it hopes that the statutory constraints which have caused such difficulty for the National Crime Authority Committee since its establishment will be promptly addressed. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

name: Coonan, Sen Helen
text:
—On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties, I present the committee's 13th report, together with submissions, transcript of evidence and minutes of proceedings. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report, to incorporate my tabling speech in Hansard  and to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted.
—I move:
That the Senate take note of the report.
The document read as follows—
The Report I have just tabled is a fairly typical one for the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties.
It deals with a total of eight agreements, two of which are on the topic of sea dumping of wastes. The other two multilateral agreements are about Australian involvement in  amendments to the International Whaling Convention the Truce Monitoring Group on Bougainville and.
The four bilateral agreements deal with amendments to a double taxation agreement, amendments to a health services agreement, an extradition treaty and an agreement on judicial assistance and cooperation. These agreements are with four quite different countries, and give some indication of the variety of work undertaken by the Treaties Committee.
The so-called London Convention will be replaced by the 1996 Protocol when sufficient countries have expressed consent to be bound by it. Our consideration of this Protocol is the subject of almost half a long chapter in this report. It is particularly appropriate for us to have reported on this matter in the International Year of the Oceans. 

We gave further consideration to this Convention in the context of the withdrawal of a previous declaration of objection about the spoil form mining of jarosite. It is good to be able to record that this mining has ceased and Australia is now able to withdraw its earlier declaration.
The third multilateral treaty we considered in this Report was the amendments agreed at the 49th Annual Meeting in October 1997 to the International Convention on the Regulation of Whaling .
Australia has been opposed to commercial whaling for many years and supported these amendments. The Committee is aware of strains within the Commission set up by the Convention and the fact that there are real concerns about the future role and viability of the Commission.
During this inquiry, at a hearing in Sydney, we took evidence from Mr Chris Puplick who was the Chairman of the National Task Force on Whaling. He was also, as many Honourable Senators will remember, a Senator for NSW for a number of years. The Report of the Task Force was an important document in the preparation of this Report. Mr Puplick's wide and detailed knowledge of the international whaling was reflected in his evidence which was of great assistance to the Committee.
The fourth multilateral agreement which is in this Report is the Agreement on the Neutral Truce Monitoring Group in Bougainville . I am sure all Honourable Senators will be aware of the tragedy which has been going on in Bougainville since 1989.
Australians, both Australian Defence Force and other non-military personnel, were involved in the Truce Monitoring Group and earned great credit by their performance. All personnel were unarmed and behaved with commendable professionalism.
The presence of a number of women was of some concern at the start of the TMG's operations. Bougainville is a matriarchal society and women members of the TMG were invited to discuss issues with village women in a way which was, of course, of considerable benefit to the peace process.
The Committee agreed unanimously in all eight cases that the Agreements should be supported. In its consideration of the various agreements which are tabled, it is providing the sort of Parliamentary scrutiny which was missing in the past.
This is a busy Committee which, having tabled this Report, is handling another three major inquiries with another to come following tabling of two further agreements last week.
I commend the Thirteenth Report of the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties to the Senate.
Debate adjourned.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—In this debate on the registration test, I am being asked to support a physical connection test for native title rights. I am being asked to be amongst the first group of politicians in Australia to dismiss the spiritual and cultural imperatives of indigenous Australians; I will not be part of this. If Senator Harradine wishes to inflict another dose of cultural genocide upon Aboriginal people, let him do that with the support of the Prime Minister and Senator Minchin. He will certainly not get my assistance to ease his conscience on that matter.
Both the government's provisions and Senator Harradine's amended physical connection test are utterly disrespectful to Aboriginal people. They are caving in to a racist paradigm which seeks to define `real' Aborigines. They ignore the shame and hurt that is felt and experienced by the stolen generations. It is one more kick in the teeth to the victims of an appalling modern day holocaust. Senator Harradine has a clear choice: his amendment does not have the numbers from the non-government parties in the Senate; either he sticks to his 1997 position, which maintains the Mabo spiritual and cultural connection test, or he supports the Howard government's despicable physical connection test.
I have no doubt that Senator Minchin at some stage soon will attempt to discredit my argument by claiming that I do not understand the legislation and that I am not aware there is a two-stage process for native title claims. So I would like to put on record that I do understand that this physical connection test applies to the registration track of the proposed two-track process. I do understand that it requires at least one member of the native title claim group to have or have had a physical connection to the land claimed. I am also aware that the regulations refer to a physical connection. I believe those regulations should be disallowed, but there is a big difference between those regulations and this legislation. 
The regulations do not prevent someone from exercising statutory native title rights. Both Senator Minchin and Senator Harradine will claim that a physical connection test is needed to provide workability to exclude multiple claims. Let me make it clear now that the physical connection test has nothing to do with workability. In fact, most of the so-called problem areas associated with overlapping claims such as the goldfields involve claimant groups who would pass even the government's draconian physical connection test.
This is not about workability; it is a direct attack on the integrity of Aboriginal culture and should be exposed as such. There is already a host of changes to the registration test which ensure that it will be far more difficult to gain registration for the purposes of gaining the right to negotiate. This physical connection test—and Senator Harradine's lawyers have said this to me—is about satisfying that racist sentiment in society that says that the indigenous people of this continent are only real Aborigines if they are still living in the bush and that, somehow, those who have moved or have been moved to places other than their traditional lands are inferior in terms of native title rights. That is what the physical connection test is about. I for one refuse to give way to this Hansonite view.
It is totally insulting for Senator Minchin to say, as he has on many occasions, that this test is necessary to establish that only bona fide claimants obtain the right to negotiate. In effect, Senator Minchin is saying that those who have been denied the ability to maintain a physical connection for whatever reason are not bona fide Aboriginals. I must say that I am ashamed to be part of a parliament where such views are expressed. I am sure that in years to come people looking back at these debates will be shocked and appalled by such views, just as millions of Australians are currently shocked and appalled by such a notion.
In essence there are two sets of reasons why the physical connection test should be opposed. The first set of reasons is associated with the short-term effects on the native title process. There are those legitimate claimants 
 who may well achieve a determination of native title based on the Mabo test who will miss out on the right to negotiate. As Aboriginal people have stated on many occasions, native title is next to useless without the right to negotiate. For Senator Minchin or Senator Harradine to claim that this physical connection test is somehow justifiable because it applies only to those wishing to claim the right to negotiate is disingenuous in the extreme.
I do not know how many registrations will be knocked out by this test, but neither does Senator Harradine nor Senator Minchin. The mere fact that there is a distinct likelihood that winnable claims will be denied the right to negotiate is sufficient for it to be rejected outright. Let us not forget, either, that the new registration regime will apply retrospectively to potentially knock out existing claims already in the right to negotiate process.
There are very serious cultural and legal problems associated with a test involving parenthood, such as that which is proposed by Senator Harradine. During the committee hearings on the bill, Professor Marcia Langton said:
The issue of apical ancestry in Aboriginal belief systems is one of belief, particularly because of such things as, say, in some Aboriginal societies there is the taboo on speaking the names of the dead.
I hope somebody is listening to this because, if we are talking about people having to establish this in a court or before they get to any legal process, and if you are dealing with cultural issues where people are unable to speak the names of the dead, then you have a problem built in.
It is not always going to be easy to establish that deceased parents had a physical connection to the land when, in some Aboriginal communities, it is actually against traditional laws to even speak the names of parents who have passed away, let alone establish a prima facie case before a tribunal, especially a native title tribunal which, under the changes proposed by section 109(2) of this bill, will not be able to take into account cultural and customary concerns which are 
 deemed to unduly prejudice any other party to the proceedings.
The other serious, and I would say fatal, flaw in Senator Harradine's amendment is the definition of `parent'. In many Aboriginal communities, a person's parent is not their biological mother or father but another member of the clan group. How does Senator Harradine, or anyone else, see the definition of `parent' being applied in a culturally appropriate manner? Again, how will it be defined by a tribunal and a Federal Court which have been restricted in their ability to take cultural and customary concerns into account?
What about when a member of the stolen generation has been adopted? In this case their legal parent may well be a European Australian, and as such they will be excluded from being a person who can qualify as a native title claim group for the right to negotiate even if their biological parent, from whom they were stolen, had maintained their cultural and spiritual connection to the land. This amendment is the height of cultural insensitivity. It will see international derision heaped upon this country. It is a cruel joke played on the Aboriginal people of this continent.
The second set of reasons why we will be opposing any form of physical connection test is perhaps even more important than the more technical issues I have already raised. It is the message it sends to the entire community about the nature of Aboriginal land rights. For the first time, this parliament will be saying that a former physical connection is necessary for a native title right to be enjoyed. How is that going to make Aboriginal and Islander people who do not pass the test feel about themselves and their cultures?
I am sure that Senator Minchin will soon invoke his mantra that only one member of the claim group needs to be able to demonstrate a physical connection for a group to be registered, but what does this effectively do to establish a hierarchy of Aboriginality within Aboriginal communities? Those people in a community who cannot pass the government's test will know that they have not been classified by the government as the types of Aborigines who can qualify their 
 claim group for the most important native title right available to indigenous communities—the right to negotiate—no matter what their history of oppression, no matter what irrepressible connection to country and culture those Aboriginal people have. This is really offensive stuff.
What sort of country is willing to sell Aboriginal culture and spirituality for all it is worth when it comes to marketing for tourism or the Olympics, yet relegates it when it comes to actually providing substantive native title rights? People in this chamber who even contemplate a physical connection test of any kind have to take a really hard look at themselves and their commitment to understanding and reconciling with the Aboriginal people of this land.
This issue highlights how totally inappropriate it is for a group of white parliamentarians—and I include myself—to be making laws about native title rights when there is no possible way that we can understand the complex nature of Aboriginal communities and their relationship with country. We run an enormous risk of making some horrendous mistakes. It is clear that the only native title rights which we should be passing into law are those which have the unadulterated and informed consent of indigenous Australians—and you could hardly say that of this bill.
I know that we have been critical of the ALP over the last few days, but I acknowledge that Senator Bolkus abhors racial discrimination and that he reflects the views of rank and file members of the Labor Party who abhor racial discrimination. I therefore trust that the ALP will also reject Senator Harradine's amendment. It may be a marginal improvement on the government's measures, yet it falls far below the standards of racial discrimination to which Senator Bolkus and the Labor Party ascribe. The ALP has promised to maintain its position of 1997. Its rejection of Senator Harradine's amendment is central to keeping that promise.
I indicate again that the Greens (WA) will not be supporting Senator Harradine's amendment, so it will not be a matter in this particular case of going from what is a preferred option to whatever happens to be left. In fact, 
 we ask Senator Harradine to withdraw the amendment to avoid bringing further shame upon this parliament. I repeat that Senator Harradine now has a clear choice either to support a test which recognises spiritual and cultural connections or to be relegated to historical infamy by supporting the government agenda.

name: Minchin, Sen Nick
text:
—I think it might be easier, given that in previous debates there has been some confusion about what we are dealing with, if we deal with the blocks as indicated and then work through them—that might be easier for everybody. Therefore, I will formally move amendments 66 to 69 so we can deal with them. I would be happy to deal with the lot at once but, if the committee prefers, in terms of dealing with government amendments first I suggest that we do it in blocks so that everybody knows what we are dealing with. The government amendments are all interrelated. If the committee finds it easier to do it that way, I am happy to oblige. I move:
(66)	 Schedule 1, item 9, page 94 (after line 18), at the end of section 30, add:
Registered native title rights and interests

		 (a)	 if the native title party is such because an entry has been made on the National Native Title Register—the native title rights and interests described in that entry; or
		 (b)	 if the native title party is such because an entry has been made on the Register of Native Title Claims—the native title rights and interests described in that entry.

name: Harradine, Sen Brian
text:
—Could I just clarify where the government amendments are that we are talking about?
—They are government amendments Nos 66 to 69 on page 17 of the sheet headed `Revised 2'. It is schedule 1, item 9, section 30 on the registration test.
—Madam Chair, it would help the committee if when indicating amendments the number of the document could be mentioned.

name: Bolkus, Sen Nick
text: —While people are looking for the description of the amendments, I will just indicate that amendment No. 66 goes to the question of native title parties. It allows for a bit more flexibility in respect of the registering on the title of those parties which have passed the registration test. We have no problem with that. Amendment No. 66 does that. Amendments Nos 67 to 69 are amendments to sections 31 and 39 and, in a sense, they are consequential amendments. They remove the words `determined or claimed' and replace them with the word `registered'. They pick up some of the concerns of native title claimants about the earlier test being a bit prohibitive. The opposition sees these amendments as beneficial and will support them.

name: Harradine, Sen Brian
text: —I wish to indicate that I have looked at those provisions and I have put a tick beside them, so I do not see any reason for delaying the committee.

name: Woodley, Sen John
text:
—I need to speak to these amendments and to indicate the Democrats' position. This section of the government's amendments is perhaps the most troubling example of what the 10-point plan is really about. When we last debated this bill in December, I spoke extensively on the issue of spiritual connection to land, not just for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders, islander Australians, but for all of us. I want to make some reference to that speech again.
I must say that, in my experience as a clergyman, when people speak about the significance of spirituality there is no doubt that for many people that is the fundamental way in which they describe their being. That is so often true of Aboriginal and other indigenous people. For that reason, we see the registration test as a trapdoor through which the government would like native title to fall. It is a hurdle that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders will have to jump to have their rights dealt with in a fair and equitable way. What is not very often understood, though, is that native title is the self-evident, manifest reality of their daily existence. Indigenous Australians do not need courts or tribunals to convince them of the existence of native title.
The whole reason that native title exists in both common law and in statutes is because white people do not, in the main, recognise indigenous reality. Native title is an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander insurance policy against the repeat of the dispossession, dishonesty and genocide of the past. To gain that insurance, Aborigines are expected to pay too high a premium—for that is what the registration test is.
I turn to Senator Harradine's amendment. This amendment requires that native title claimants have to prove not only that they had an association with the land but also that they have had regular physical access to the land. There is the qualification of an additional generation with the physical connection and we recognise that as an improvement, but the Democrats could not support this amendment. We believe that the physical connection test is flawed in morality and in law. The Democrats do not accept that, in moving this amendment, Senator Harradine has given enough consideration to issues such as those raised in the recent report on the stolen generation whereby many Aboriginal people were forcibly removed from their families and continuous physical relationship with the land was deemed impossible. I add that, with successive governments in Queensland of all complexions, it was government policy to move people from one end of the state to the other. 
I will give a couple of examples. One of the communities which has been spoken about on a number of occasions in this chamber is the community at Mapoon on western Cape York. Part of the reason that the Mapoon people are having such a struggle in resolving native title is that, even amongst themselves, there is confusion about who really belongs to that community, so a distinction has been made between historical and traditional people. The traditional people are those who can trace their ancestry back many generations, whereas historical people are people whose grandparents, perhaps, or great-grandparents were moved to Mapoon from many other parts of northern Queensland. For them Mapoon is also their land, but a distinction is made between those who can trace their ancestry back many generations and those who have an ability to trace their ancestry back only two or three generations.
This whole issue is compounded by the fact that, in the early 1960s, the people were driven out of Mapoon. Some of them went to Thursday Island, some of them went to New Mapoon near Bamaga on the tip of Cape York, some of them went to Aurukun, and some of them went to Weipa. So again the removal of people was compounded.
I have spoken on a number of occasions to some of the ancestors of the Mapoon people. In Cairns, for instance, a large group of them are trying to understand how they can reclaim their community. It is not a pastoral lease but the community has mining interests all around it. The people in the community want to re-establish their own community, yet they have this problem. If the registration test as proposed is applied, we will have to say to a whole group of people from Mapoon, `Sorry, you don't qualify.'
The next example comes from Rosalind Kidd's book, The Way We Civilise It, from which I quoted a few days ago. In the community of Yarrabah near Cairns, almost all the people have come from somewhere else. What community do they belong to? That is the question that they ask. Many of them do not know where they came from, but Yarrabah has become their community. What kind of connection is required of them? Then there 
 is the example from the time of the Second World War. Pastor Schwartz was the missionary at Cape Bedford in Cape York. Because he was a German he was regarded as a Nazi sympathiser. The belief was that he had perhaps infected the community at Cape Bedford, so the military authorities demanded that the mission be disbanded. Reverend Schwartz was kept under armed guard and his belongings were searched. The mission car was confiscated in 1942, leaving no transport for medical emergencies, et cetera. The 271 residents of Cape Bedford were transported about 2,000 kilometres to the Aboriginal community at Woorabinda in central Queensland.
The relocation was appallingly bungled. Under military and police guard, people were refused time to gather clothing and belongings. Apart from a meal at Cooktown, no food was available next morning, nor on the 14-hour boat trip to Cairns, nor on the overnight train until 5.30 a.m. the next day at Cardwell. Nothing was provided from that evening until Rockhampton was reached the following afternoon. Woorabinda was nowhere near ready to accept them and to cut a long story short—and if I had time, I would certainly recall all of the disaster of this removal—
—Please don't!
—I think I should for your sake, Senator Boswell. I might say that this happened under a Labor government.
Many of those people died. What kind of physical connection test are you going to apply to them? To what community do they belong, Cape Bedford in Far North Queensland or Woorabinda in Central Queensland? This is the problem that we have with the definition of the registration test that the government, and certainly Senator Harradine in his amendment, are putting upon us. I know there is considerable support for the refining of the registration test. I think everyone agrees with that. But it cannot be so refined that it creates a situation where the registration test is so onerous that it effectively wipes out accessibility to native title procedures.
It really is an issue of access to justice. A harsh test is not the issue. The injustice flows 
 from a harsh test in combination with unreasonably tight time frames from notices that will have the effect of impairing or extinguishing native title. We believe the government is attempting to say to native title applicants, `Sure you can have native title. You even have native title procedures. Just use them but don't expect us to make them work.'
On the other hand, the Democrat-Greens (WA) amendments will ensure that there are no technical knockouts of native title. Professor Langton, whom I mentioned in my earlier speech, in response to a question from Senator Ferris on overlapping claims—the main excuse the government is using to substantiate such a massive high jump bar for indigenous people to access their rights—said:
So, in answer to Senator Ferris's question, I wanted to explain the problem in this way. I spoke before about how one of the principles which anthropologists have identified in order to ascertain the workings of an Aboriginal land tenure system is the notion of descent from an apical ancestor.
As with all human cultures, the ancestor may be real or legendary, to use a lay term. For instance, British royalty had at one time its constitution in divinity and it was believed that the king, or the queen, was the divine representative on earth.
It was called `the divine right of kings'. She continued:
That is why the monarch is the representative of the Church of England, because of the doctrine of the monarch as divinity.
In a similar way, most human cultures have a belief system about ancestry. These days with DNA and RNA testing, some of this can be affirmed or denied, but much of it still is not amenable to scientific inquiry. Belief systems are belief systems and as we know with racism, generally false propositions which operate on illogic are not amendable to facts. So in the same way belief systems are simply belief systems and there is no point in taking blood tests and doing DNA tests because it is not relevant to the exercise. One would not do a DNA test on the queen to see if she were, in fact, a descendant of God.
That is rather a strange notion. Professor Langton went on to say a number of other things. That is available to us all in the transcript of that hearing.
When we take into consideration the genocide that has happened to indigenous people, 
 the provision of a physical connection test is an amendment that could easily have been drafted by the discredited historian David Irving. I appeal to the government and to the Senate to accept the Greens and Democrat amendments as fulfilling the need for a registration test which will sort out the various problems that have been enunciated.
We cannot accept Senator Harradine's amendment because it is based, we believe, on a false premise. We do recognise that Senator Harradine's amendment does improve the government's registration test, but neither the government's test nor the improvement which Senator Harradine is moving fulfils the basic principle that I have enunciated: the principle that, in the end, there are spiritual and cultural connections to land which are far deeper than any physical connection and that sometimes those kinds of connections can last for 200, 500 or 1,000 years, as in the case of the Jewish people—an example I gave in my previous speech. I commend our amendments to the committee.

name: Harradine, Sen Brian
text:
—Madam Chair, I am at a bit of a loss to know where we are. I thought we were dealing with government amendment 66.
—We are dealing with government amendments 66 to 69.
—Since everybody has been speaking generally, let me speak fairly briefly at this stage. I reject completely the statements that have been made about my amendment and I will come to that when I move the amendment. My amendment is to ensure that indigenous groups or members of indigenous groups who have been locked out by pastoralists or by actions of government, or those members of indigenous groups who have been stolen—the stolen generation—will be specifically included in the registration test, even if there is not one of their group currently alive who at some stage, even as a baby, has set foot on the land.
I said in the beginning of this debate that I am not prepared to see a diminution of the common law rights of indigenous Australians to their land. I stand by that. The fact that is being forgotten here is that for those indigen 
 ous groups to be entitled to native title they must have connection and descent, and the land must not have been subject to extinguishment. That is the CDE test. I think people have forgotten that. We are talking about native title; we are talking about the decisions in Mabo; we are talking about decisions in Wik. If you look at those, you do need CDE. You need contact, connection and descent because, in Mabo, the basis for native title was the rejection of the legal fiction, terra nullius. That is what we are dealing with here.
In order to ensure that we are giving an avenue to the genuine native title owners of the land we must establish some sort of registration test.
—There is one. There is one built in.
—Senator Margetts says, `There is one.' After Waanyi, there is one? Have a word with persons within the indigenous communities and see how they feel about it. They feel that there should be a test which allows genuine native title holders to get into the first track.
—As opposed to only those with spiritual connections.
—Wait a minute. I will come to the spiritual connection in a minute. Have a word to others who are interested, including miners, pastoralists, governments and country townspeople—or city townspeople, for that matter. Those who want to see the High Court decisions upheld want to see a situation where all bogus claims are prevented from being successful and the huge number of overlapping claims which beset those who are concerned about this matter not able to get through the threshold test. What is wrong with that? What is wrong with having a proper test?
We are looking at a question now of what the High Court said. We do need to recognise that the High Court made it clear which indigenous people are entitled to a recognition of their native title. The High Court recognised that native title existed, and it recognised that native title should be recognised by the community where there is connection and 
 descent to the people who owned that land in 1788 when the first Europeans came to this land.
I now go to the arguments on the bill itself. In section 190B(5) the bill requires the registrar to be `satisfied that the factual basis described in the application . . . is sufficient to support the assertion that the native title rights and interests claimed exist.' Government amendment 73 expands that provision to spell out clearly that the factual basis on which it is asserted that native title rights	 and interests exist derives from the Mabo decision.
In section 190B(6) the bill requires the registrar to consider `that, prima facie, each of the native title rights and interests claimed in the application can be established.' There have been negotiations about this and I have made it perfectly clear to the government that I am concerned that that is too restrictive. Government amendment 73 changes this to `some rights and interests'. Previously, as the government wanted it, it said `. . . each of the native title rights and interests claimed in the application can be established'. The government has said `Okay, we will change this to `some rights and interests'.
Another amendment set up a register of those interests, including the spiritual interests and cultural interests of the indigenous group, which is very important to their connection to the land. I believe that this is a very significant amendment as it enables the native title claimant to be registered even if they are unable within the very strict time limits that are in the legislation to establish all of the claimed native title rights and interests.
To further improve this situation, opposition N34—perhaps, Senator Bolkus, that could be moved separately when the time comes—allows the register to be amended after registration so that native title claimants, when they come to negotiate, are able to negotiate about all the native title rights and interests which are then registered. That not only gives certainty to the pastoralists, the governments and those who need to consider the matters but also it gives a degree of certainty to the native title claimants. That is good.
The bill, in section 190B(7), introduces the traditional physical connection test which is not, strictly speaking, part of the common law test for the existence of native title. Unfortunately, many people seem to have been convinced that a requirement for a physical connection test is necessary to bring order into native title law. The amendments to the threshold test package which I have spoken about above will do far more to eradicate the spurious and scandalous claims than a physical connection test. When I said, `spoken about above', I meant the matters that I raised in this chamber in December. Honourable senators, if they are interested, can either go back to those or read the document entitled `Native Title Amendment Bill 1997: the Senate's amendments to the threshold test'. That is an eight-page document that was provided to me by my legal advisers.
If the government is insistent on this test, it needs to be ameliorated to ensure that those indigenous people who have been the victims of the locked gate and stolen generation problems are not prevented from having their claims registered when they have not given up their native title rights and interests to the lands of their ancestors. It is important for us to receive examples of this. As yet, I have not received examples of that situation. It is important to have some examples presented to us so that support can be maintained.
The government has gone some way to providing this situation in government amendment 73(7)(b). This does not go far enough given the fact that many of the victims of those policies and incidents, due to the scandalously low life expectancy among the indigenous, may no longer be living. Hence I propose to move N4 to add an extra generation to the government's physical connection test.
I come to Senator Woodley. Of all those people about whom he speaks, is there not any one of that indigenous group who is alive who, maybe as a child, was on that area? We are getting down to the practicalities now. I believe it is important when we deal with legislation to have a good understanding of what is being proposed and examples of how the amendments that are being put forward 
 are going to somehow affect the rights of particular individuals.
The bill, in section 190B(8), does not add anything to the threshold test package. An application must not be made unless there is compliance with the matters set out in section 61A. However, this provision puts an obligation on to the registrar to ensure that the application does comply with section 61A prior to its being registered.
The bill, in section 190B(9), required the registrar not to register a claim where the native title rights and interests consisted of or included ownership of minerals (Extension of time granted) where the Crown owned the minerals. Since it is possible that native title rights may include ownership of minerals in circumstances where the Crown at common law has ownership, that provision went too far. The government's amendment No. 73 inserts the word `wholly' to take care of the situation where the Crown's radical title to minerals may be burdened by native title.

name: Bolkus, Sen Nick
text:
—Earlier I spoke in general about the issues involved here. I suppose, like Senator Harradine, I thought we were going through the amendments sequentially. I have already indicated what the opposition will be doing regarding amendments 66 to 69. I want to spend a few minutes considering the core issue of this part of the debate, and that is the threshold test—the registration test—and how it should operate.
The core issue is this: who is a genuine native title holder? How can that be resolved through the process? As Senator Harradine has said, a number of us in this place, in the community and among the working group are concerned that we are able to distinguish the bogus, fraudulent and overlapping claims from the genuine ones but, in doing so, we must ensure that there is still a course open for those with genuine claims to be able to pursue them.
In essence, the parliament needs to see how the High Court test in Mabo No. 2 can be best applied. When one listens to the debate, it is quite apparent that there are different views—those of the government; the opposition, which has a view shared with the Greens 
 and the Democrats; and Senator Harradine. In a numbers sense, we are skating on thin ice and hopefully something will come up, through the evolving debate, and the votes.
We think that the government's position goes too far. It is too restrictive and it is a curtailment of the High Court test. We are concerned that we not go too far in taking away common law rights and we are concerned that the government's proposal does in fact that. At the same time, we are concerned that it does not allow a course for some genuine claims to be pursued. Our amendments provide not just for the single test in the government's bill—the physical connection test, which is reflected in the government's amendment 73(7)—but ensure also that three tests apply in the alternative. The amendment that we are pursuing today is identical to the amendment that we pursued in the debate last November and December.
We accepted then the test put up by the government at the time of traditional physical association—that is, that one member of the native title claim group has or previously had a traditional physical connection with the area. That is still the first leg of our three-part test. In the alternative, we felt it imperative that the parliament take into account the injustice related to those who had been locked out and were denied traditional physical association. It would have been quite unreasonable for the parliament not to have recognised the importance of factoring in the position of those who were dispossessed of their land by lock-outs or by other actions forced upon them. That constitutes the second part of our test.
The third part of our test is, in essence, to pick up the words of Mr Justice Brennan in Mabo. For us, it is important that, if the parliament is to be seen to be reflecting the full impact of the common law, then the words of Justice Brennan should be reflected in legislation. I remind senators that he said:
Where a clan or group has continued to acknowledge the laws and (so far as practicable) to observe the customs based on the traditions of the clan or group, whereby their traditional connexion with the land has been substantially maintained, the traditional community title of that clan or group can be said to remain in existence. 

In other words, there should be an avenue for them also to pursue native title claims.
We are concerned that these two aspects of connection—the physical and, as a subset of physical, the denied physical, together with traditional association with the land—are still maintained in a threshold test which, at the same time, ensures that the bogus, fraudulent and overlapping claims can be dealt with. They are dealt with comprehensively in other aspects of the legislation already passed through the parliament and still to be considered here. One way or another, we are still concerned that this avenue be made available.
Let us keep in mind also that we are not dealing with these three alternatives in isolation. We are dealing with them given that the legislation, as passed last year and as to be passed this year, ensures that the evidentiary burden is much higher than it was in the pre-existing legislation. There has to be establishment of a prima facie case. A whole raft of requirements were adopted by the Senate last year that ensure that, not just in terms of overlaps but also in terms of the burden of proof. At a very preliminary stage the burden is such that much of the flotsam and jetsam, I suppose it could be called, is not allowed to go to base one.
Our position is to reflect that. Our position is to acknowledge that this test will work within a framework as has already been deliberated by the parliament. Our other objective is to ensure that we meet the requirements of common law. You are talking about potentially taking away the common law rights of people. No matter what anyone says or what interpretation one gives to the case in the High Court last week, it is fair to say that anyone who reads that case will come away with not just a feeling but an understanding that to take away one's common law rights would meet with a different response—a stronger response—from the High Court.
We have to ensure that we do not do that. Senator Harradine says, `Well, give us an example where, by deleting the Mabo-Brennan test, you are denying people access to justice and access to their rights.' There are instances involving people on Palm Island in the Forties where, with careful consideration, 
 it may very well be that those people would be denied access under either the Harradine or the government test. We say that, if the view is that no-one will qualify under this particular test, there is no cost to anyone if we play it safe and ensure that this avenue is available to people.
There is some concern that the physical connection, as proposed by either Senator Harradine or Senator Minchin, is too restrictive. As I said, people in and around Palm Island in The Forties, for instance, may be denied access to native title claims because of the operation of the alternative test proposed. We will be pursuing our amendment that adopted last year. We see Senator Harradine's as a second best. We see the government's proposal as excessively restrictive and we will not be able to support that.

name: Brown, Sen Bob
text:
—I thank Senator Bolkus for that clear exposition on why Senator Harradine's proposal is going to fall short of the mark. Senator Harradine's amendment cuts out a whole category that was available last year and that was argued by the committee, including Senator Harradine, on very cogent grounds. That category defends the rights of indigenous people to make a claim through traditional connection with the land, even if they have been locked out or fail to have a direct connection in the interim.
Senator Harradine said that my amendment was to ensure persons who have been locked out will be specifically included, but he meant some persons who have been locked out will be specifically included. What his amendment does is water down, withdraw from and reduce even the tests that were voted on by the Senate in December last year. In particular, it is taking away from many people their spiritual and traditional connection, which is the foundation of their connection with the land. It is taking that away as a tenable and acceptable claim when people want to reconnect themselves with the land.
Let us remember this: on all of these occasions, these people have not wanted to be disconnected. Their history is not one of wanting to leave. There is a terrible history involved here, and time and time again it has 
 been visited on indigenous people and time and time again, through fraudulence, force or trickery, they have been removed from their land. Senator Woodley gave a gruesome account of how recently that has occurred on a large scale in Queensland, and we have to remember that.
I do not hear Senator Harradine getting up and being concerned about spurious and scandalous claims from people other than the indigenous people involved in this situation. The pall of potential misuse of this legislation hangs across the indigenous people. Why should that be the case? Why is it that Senator Harradine is moving back from the position that was held just last year, that he defended just last year?
I have two questions that I wish to have answered at the end of my comments. My first question is to Senator Minchin, who indicated on the weekend that a connection with the land is enough to give people the right to make a claim. I ask this: is any connection enough? Is a visit to the land enough? Can the government tell the committee if a visit to the land at some time in the past is enough to allow a traditional owner to make a claim?
My second question is to Senator Harradine. After Diaspora, did the Israelites have no right to go back to Israel? Did the generations of disconnection disclaim them? Are you opposed to the process of this century which saw the Jewish people going back to Israel, the return of the Israelites? That is what you are proposing here, Senator Harradine.
—Was there no Israelite who had a physical connection test alive at that stage?
—Let us presume there was not. There are two standards here.
—Bullshit!
—Senator Harradine might say `bullshit', but I am saying that there are two standards here and he has just been discovered exhibiting them.
—Madam Chairman, I raise a point of order. I ask that the senators withdraw that offensive word.
—I withdraw.
—I will withdraw the repetition of the comment, but it points out that Senator Harradine has discovered here—and it is something I maintain—that, if a spiritual connection, a historic connection, a longing which is clear and patent, is good enough for people at the core of Christian tradition, it is good enough for people at the core of Aboriginal spiritual tradition. To not see that parallel and to back one but not the other is to discriminate, and that is again what is happening here.
I was at Doomadgee in the gulf country last year and I met up again with one of the wonderful members of the Gunggalida community, Wadgular Binna. As we were standing in the bush there, a group of us put to her that at that stage it looked like spiritual connection may be discounted, even as far as negotiations on mining were concerned. Her response was instant: `Take away our spirituality and you take away our hearts. That is taking the hearts out of us as people.' We should remember that. There are too many broken hearts in the last two and a bit centuries of the history of the indigenous people in this country. We have to do the best we can, because not one indigenous person is here to be able to speak up for that feeling they have for the land. We have to try to put ourselves in their position and, if we do, we will be found wanting.
There are double standards being employed here and it is not a very nice process. Senator Margetts began with very, very strong words about cultural genocide this afternoon, but she is right. She is right that this is another process of dispossession, of killing culture, of killing connections, of killing hopes. I cannot understand it, and I have heard no argument here as to why we should retreat from the minimal position that the Senate accepted in December.

name: Harradine, Sen Brian
text:
—May I respond, and I do apologise to the committee for the remark that I made. I do feel that Senator Brown has misunderstood totally what native title is all about.
—A mutual misunderstanding, it seems.
—Let us test that. This bill is not about granting native title. This parliament is not about granting native title. To do that, we are virtually saying that we in this parliament have to act paternalistically to indigenous people in Australia who have native title. Even the High Court did not grant them native title. It recognised that they had native title.
—But you're taking it away.
—In this particular regard, some people are talking about a traditional physical connection to land. That traditional physical connection may have commenced at the beginning of this century, and you are saying that you will put an `or' there so that those people are entitled to a native title to that land. You are not going to get such a claim recognised because it has to fit within Mabo. That is the whole point about it.
Mabo is essential to the success of a native title claim, absolutely essential. To say that Mabo or a physical connection means you could get registration, even if you cannot satisfy Mabo, is a nonsense. Of course you cannot. You have to prove CDE—connection, descent and that extinguishment has not taken place on the land. Let us get that clear in our heads. That is what it is all about. If you are operating on a basis of misunderstanding there, as I suspect that you are—
—Well, you're wrong.
—Have a look at what you have been saying over this period—and I will be happy to have a look at the Hansard . You are really not understanding that Mabo is essential to the success of a native title claim.
Let us be perfectly clear: my amendment will ensure that those dispossessed in the last two generations will be able to be registered. That is what my amendment does. You, Senator Brown, through you, Madam Chairman, are going to vote against that. When the time comes—and we will deal with it then—you are going to vote against that.
—You're going to vote against yourself.
—I am moving the amendment. I am not likely to be voting against it. I refer to a point that Senator Woodley made, and I just ask him about the areas and the peoples he was concerned about. The committee has to ask itself: is there no-one alive today who lived on that land? That is what you have to ask yourself. Is there no-one alive today who actually lived on that land, even if they were an infant and are now living a thousand miles away?
It might be desirable for the committee, rather than toing and froing, to get to a situation where we can have an amendment before us that we are voting on. As I understand it, the amendment that is before us is government amendment No. 66, is it not?
—It is 66 to 69.
—Can we get rid of that, and then I am happy to debate the issues when they come forward?

name: Woodley, Sen John
text:
—I hear Senator Harradine's appeal. I have been seeking to debate all of the amendments, or at least those that hang together, because then, when we come to them, we can move through the voting fairly succinctly. If that is not so, I am happy to be guided by other people.
Senator Harradine did ask me a question about whether there were any people alive. Of course there are, otherwise they could not make a claim. The problem is, however, Senator Harradine, as I was saying, in making the physical connection the fundamental test, even going back a generation, you still do not solve the problem for those people I was speaking about. Take the Mapoon case: you have different groups of people, all of whom have a physical connection, making different claims, and some claims were not being allowed because even the degrees of physical connection were being debated. That was the problem.
Let me see if I can help us with a way through. The Democrats agree there must be a registration test but the real problem is the resourcing of representative bodies. That is where the problem has come about in trying 
 to apply the registration test where we have had overlapping claims and, in Senator Harradine's words, some bogus claims as well. Where even the 1993 act itself has been used and the representative bodies have been able to operate properly, they have been able to resolve those overlapping claims.
Take the example which is quoted regularly of the whole Kalgoorlie area and the goldfields. Just last week the Goldfields Land Council pointed out to me that by using the 1993 act they had been able, through negotiation, to collapse the 57 overlapping claims into two and in fact are now, through discussions with the mining companies in that area, on the point of signing agreements very beneficial to all the parties involved. So if the representative bodies are properly resourced, then even by using the 1993 act they are able to resolve the whole problem of overlapping claims. But the resourcing is critical.
Even in the 1993 act, bogus claims are knocked out. `Vexatious and frivolous claims'—I think is the wording—are not allowed. There have been vexatious and frivolous claims made—I have no doubt about that—but they are being dealt with, and they can be dealt with under the 1993 act, let alone under any amendments that we might propose.
Senator Harradine is right—many of these claims will not succeed simply because the native title has already been extinguished. I would point out that Mabo actually also said that the doctrine of terra nullius was null and void. By abolishing that doctrine, in one sense the whole of the continent should be open to claim. But, of course, as we know, the 1993 act made it quite clear that many parts of the continent are not subject to claim and native title has been extinguished in many parts of it.
I do not know whether I want to open up the debate about the Jewish people, but the point I was trying to make was that, again, a physical connection is not required of people who want to return to the state of Israel. The ancestors of some of those people have been separated for 200, 500, a thousand, two thousand years. In fact, you would have to go into myth and legend if you tried to trace any 
 connection between the current state of Israel and the original tribes of Israel. Nevertheless, Jewish people have a very strong connection. It is not physical connection; it is cultural connection. It is a connection of spirit; a connection of race, if you like.
The same problem, however, exists in many other parts of the world. The dispossession of the Scots, the Irish or the Welsh from their lands has never been properly settled. Those issues remain today. It is only as we negotiate with people properly and sit down with them that we begin to solve those problems. I am glad to see that, at least in relation to Scotland and Wales, there are now ways through after 700 years in some cases. Unfortunately, the Irish problem remains with us.
What we are saying is there are historical examples which give us pause. There is no direct connection between them. But what they say to us is, in terms of history, we need to learn the lessons that you need to deal with people with respect and deal with them properly. We need to negotiate outcomes which people can own and live with. Otherwise, the sore will continue to fester until finally it has to be dealt with. That is my contribution.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—Senator Harradine mentioned in this debate this afternoon that someone would have had to—and I took it down—`set foot as a baby on the land.' Schedule 2, part 1, on page 206 of the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 [No. 2], relates to physical connection. Proposed subsection (7) states:
The Registrar must be satisfied that at least one member of the native title claim group currently has or previously had a traditional physical connection with the area covered by application.
So we are not talking about `set foot as a baby'; we are talking about lived in what is considered to be a traditional physical connection with the area. I am wondering where this might lead to in the end. This might lead to the actual footprints—the tracks where people stood. Maybe we will get so tight in revisiting this over time that only those places which were regularly trod will become the areas where registration is accepted. I believe that it is a problem.
Over time concern has been expressed to me by a number of people, including the very people with whom Senator Harradine danced the other day. Gladys said to me, `I hope Senator Harradine understands this is a dance about our land and our culture.' I am not sure he did. The information I have received from the Mirimbiak nation's aboriginal corporation talks about the cases in Victoria, Victoria having a history of close occupation. I will read some parts from this letter:
Further, it may affect the way national laws regarding Indigenous people are implemented in Victoria. It may affect the way the registration test is implemented. Therefore the test itself should be carefully drafted to prevent perpetuating this stereotype.
. . .              . . .             . . .
This requirement emphasises the government's conception of native title as something that purely exists in the physical domain. It emphasises the need as expressed by the State Government for native title holders to prove physical connection and presence on land, before any claims to spiritual connection will even be considered. Victorian Aboriginal people are not seen as having been on the land—"they have all been assimilated".
It goes on, and this, I believe, is a statement from the court:
It may amount to a pre-judgement about the nature of native title in Victoria.
It is inappropriate, before trial, for the nature of native title in Victoria to be pre-judged by the imposition of a threshold test, which may impose the wider community's pre-conceptions of what is Aboriginality. This will have particular pernicious effects in Victoria.
It is not the only way to achieve that end.
The most appropriate means of addressing the "problem" of over-lapping and ambit claims is by means of a well resourced, strong, and accountable—both legally and culturally—representative body. Mirimbiak is part of the way to achieving these aims with Victoria's native title holders. To date, there are no overlapping claims in Victoria.
I just wondered if Senator Harradine did a statistical analysis. I do not think this is about numbers, but it seems to be the way Senator Harradine is presenting it. If you did a statistical analysis of those potential claims which may now or retrospectively be either questioned or declared invalid, are these the claims that are likely to be associated with 
 overlapping claims? I have never argued that overlapping claims are a problem per se.
—Why?
—I have mentioned this on several occasions. The problem that existed in 1993 was the fact that the bill was drafted for white land law. It was therefore impossible to assume that Aboriginal land law would fit neatly and conveniently within European or white land law. It is our expectations of land connection and land ownership about Aboriginal people which, on a number of occasions, have created the problem. There are overlapping land associations depending on the situation, depending on the season, depending on the clan group. That is Aboriginal culture. There are times when people speak for themselves. There are times when people speak for wider groups. There are times when they cannot speak for their land connections without particular circumstances being involved. There are circumstances where different groups can speak for the same area of land. They are legitimate multiple claims.
Aboriginal people are being required to deal sometimes with hundreds of mining claims on the land for which they speak. We do not seem to think that that is a problem. We do not extinguish mining claims for that reason. I believe the problem is, in many cases, firstly, the way some cowboy corporations are acting and misusing the act and, secondly, the resourcing that is available not just to land councils but to other representative bodies—they could be corporations or other Aboriginal bodies—who are trying to deal with the issues and represent the people for whom they are set up.
This is important. When I spoke last on this issue, I talked about the situation in Western Australia. I talked about a situation where the health of a particular person or the failing health of a particular person may, if this bill goes through in this form, be the defining condition of whether or not a claim is recognised. I have a statement I would like to read from the Swan Valley Nyungah Community, a statement concerning their spiritual connection to the land and the 10-point plan. They say: 
The Spiritual Beliefs cannot be separated from the Aboriginal People or the Land.
The Spiritual Connection to the Land is a given thing to us by Birthright and cannot be changed.
