	 Question put.

name: Woodley, Sen John
text:
—I seek leave to defer the Democrat-Greens (WA) amendments until after we have dealt with Senator Harradine's amendment.
—You do not need leave because it has not been moved.

name: Minchin, Sen Nick
text:
—Madam Chair, I understood it was agreed that we would now move to government amendment No. 73 before moving to Senator Harradine's amendment N4. I understood that was the procedure that we all agreed on. Government amendment No. 73 reads:
(73)	 Schedule 2, item 63, page 205 (line 22) to page 206 (line 28), omit subsections (5) to (10), substitute:
Factual basis for claimed native title
(5)	 The Registrar must be satisfied that the factual basis on which it is asserted that the native title rights and interests claimed exist is sufficient to support the assertion. In particular, the factual basis must support the following assertions:
	 (a)	 that the native title claim group have, and the predecessors of those persons had, an association with the area; and
	 (b)	 that there exist traditional laws acknowledged by, and traditional customs observed by, the native title claim group that give rise to the claim to native title rights and interests; and
	 (c)	 that the native title claim group have continued to hold the native title in accordance with those traditional laws and customs.
Prima facie case
(6)	 The Registrar must consider that, prima facie, at least some of the native title rights and interests claimed in the application can be established.
	 Note:	 If the claim is accepted for registration, the Registrar must, under paragraph 186(1)(g), enter on the Register of Native Title Claims details of only those claimed native title rights and interests that can, prima facie, be established. Only those rights and interests 
 are taken into account for the purposes of subsection 31(2) (which deals with negotiation in good faith in a "right to negotiate" process) and subsection 39(1) (which deals with criteria for making arbitral body determinations in a "right to negotiate" process).
Physical connection
(7)	 The Registrar must be satisfied that at least one member of the native title claim group:
	 (a)	 currently has or previously had a traditional physical connection with any part of the land or waters covered by the application; or
	 (b)	 previously had and would reasonably have been expected currently to have a traditional physical connection with any part of the land or waters but for things done (other than the creation of an interest in relation to land or waters) by:
		 (i)	 the Crown in any capacity; or
		 (ii)	 a statutory authority of the Crown in any capacity; or
		 (iii)	 any other person.
No failure to comply with section 61A
(8)	 The application and accompanying documents must not disclose, and the Registrar must not otherwise be aware, that, because of section 61A (which forbids the making of applications where there have been previous native title determinations or exclusive or non-exclusive possession acts), the application should not have been made.
No extinguishment etc. of claimed native title
(9)	 The application and accompanying documents must not disclose, and the Registrar must not otherwise be aware, that:
	 (a)	 to the extent that the native title rights and interests claimed consist of or include ownership of minerals, petroleum or gas—the Crown in right of the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory wholly owns the minerals, petroleum or gas; or
	 (b)	 to the extent that the native title rights and interests claimed relate to waters in an offshore place—those rights and interests purport to exclude all other rights and interests in relation to the whole or part of the offshore place; or
	 (c)	 in any case—the native title rights and interests claimed have otherwise been extinguished (except to the extent that the extinguishment is required to be disregarded under subsection 47(2), 47A(2) or 47B(2)).  

—Senator Bolkus, you have an amendment to government amendment No. 73—N37.

name: Bolkus, Sen Nick
text:
—Indeed, I do, but I would have thought it more appropriate for Senator Harradine's amendment to go first here. I move:
(N37)	 Section 190B(6), omit "some", substitute "one".
Our amendment to government amendment No. 73 amends subsection 190B(6) such that native title claimants must only establish prima facie one rather than some of the native title rights. Given the fact that claimants who had established only one right or interest to access the right to negotiate under the current act, the government's requirement for some rights to be established is unreasonable, not in line with other parts of the act and artificial as a consequence.
If we are going to be faced with the government's test here, then at least we should consider amending it to ensure it is in line with other aspects of the act. So trying to achieve that result, we wish to amend it to ensure that the claimants must establish prima facie grounds for only one rather than some of the native title rights. I think the government could accept that.

name: Minchin, Sen Nick
text: —I indicate that we are not able to accept opposition amendment N37. We think it is unnecessary. The amendment proposed by the government takes away the notion that each and every right claimed has to be proved for the claim to be registered or prima facie established. We have changed the wording to acknowledge that we are not expecting that registration would not be successful if just one of a number of rights claimed is not able to be proved. We are not prepared to modify it any further.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text: —I am indicating that the Greens (WA) will be supporting opposition amendment N37.

name: Harradine, Sen Brian
text:
—As the minister said, this government 
 amendment has taken into account the principal issues that were of concern and it certainly turns around what was previously in the government legislation. So I think, to a certain extent at least, that has been taken care of.
—The question is that opposition amendment N37 be agreed to.
Question resolved in the negative.
—The question is that government amendment 73 be agreed to.

name: Harradine, Sen Brian
text:
—Madam Chair, I would like to move N4, which is on page 3 of the amendments.
—Senator Harradine, my understanding is that your N4 does not amend government amendment 73. It is separate to it.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—Madam Chair, Senator Harradine has indicated he is willing to move N4 now, and I am very happy to allow him to do it.
—It is not possible because it is not an amendment to government amendment 73. It is additional to government amendment 73. It adds to it; it does not alter it. The question is that government amendment 73 be agreed
	 Question put:
	 That the amendment (Senator Minchin's ) be agreed to.

name: Bolkus, Sen Nick
text:
—I would like to make a couple of comments at this stage in respect of that vote and the next vote. All the way through this debate, the opposition has said that its preferred option is the one with three avenues of claim. That, of course, was defeated a few moments ago. I also said that our second preferred option was the Harradine proposal, which accommodates an extra generation of people. To get to the Senator Harradine proposal one had to ensure that there was something there to amend. Our support for the previous motion before the chamber lays the groundwork for us to pick up the Harradine amendment.
The role of the amendments has meant that at some stage difficult decisions have to be made by us all. People made a difficult decision in respect of the opposition amendment. People had to make a difficult decision as to the government amendment to ensure that there was a platform to pursue the Harradine amendment as a second option. People now have to make a difficult assess 
 ment as to whether to accept the Harradine amendment to the government proposal or to allow the government proposal to go through unamended.
It is very important that the Harradine amendment—which, as I said earlier, is a major improvement on the government's proposal and is a second best to our amendment in our eyes—now be carried by the Senate. Without going through the previous debate, I re-emphasise the point that a lot of people will be enfranchised by the Harradine amendment who would be disenfranchised if that amendment were not carried by the Senate. I hope that the numbers are there for it to be carried.
—On a point of order: I draw your attention, Madam Chair, to the procedure whereby an amendment was made to the legislation and now we are being asked to deal with an amendment to that amendment.
—It is not an amendment to the amendment. Senator Bolkus was not correct. Senator Harradine's amendment is an addition.
—Thank you, Madam Chair, for your considerate response to my easygoing question! I just point out that you will have to resolve that with Senator Bolkus who just said that it is an amendment to the amendment.
—I think Senator Bolkus has just taken the point that I have made.
—My office has been looking through this, and Senator Harradine could not have made that amendment until that amendment was passed. In fact, Senator Harradine's amendment is an amendment to the amendment we have just passed.
—It is an addition to it; it is not altering the substance. I have been given advice that that is the case, and that is my understanding. I am calling Senator Harradine. Do you wish to disagree, Senator Margetts?
—I just suggest that when we have amendments which are in addition, we generally call them amendments.
—But they are additional; they are not altering the substance of the amendment that the government was moving.

name: Harradine, Sen Brian
text:
—I move:
(N4)	 Schedule 2, item 3, page 206, line 28, at the end of section 190B, add:
	 (11)	 For the purposes of the operation of paragraph (7)(b), the reference to a member of the native title claim group will be taken to include a reference to the parent of a member of the native title claim group.
This amendment is an addition to the amendment to the Native Title Amendment Bill which has just been carried by the committee. I will not take long because we canvassed the matter in the amendment earlier today. I hope the government and the committee as a whole looks favourably on this particular measure. The government is insistent upon its test, but this ameliorates it so as to ensure that indigenous people who have been victims of the stolen generation and locked gates problems are not prevented from having their claims registered when they have not given up their native title rights and interests to the land of their ancestors.
After discussion, the government has gone some way—and I admit this—to providing for this situation in subsection (b) of the amendment that has just been passed by the committee. But in my view this does not go far enough, given the fact that many of the victims of those policies and incidents, due to the scandalously low life expectancy of indigenous people, are no longer alive. Hence, I am moving this additional amendment. I am doing so by adding an extra generation to the government's physical connection test. I commend the legislation to the committee and hope, notwithstanding what has been said thus far in the chamber, that honourable senators will realise that this is a very significant additional amendment to the Native Title Amendment Bill.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—Madam Chair, I am not entirely sure at which point an amendment becomes a bill. Perhaps I could be advised at which 
 point, when the Senate makes amendments, they become part of the bill.
—When the amendment has been agreed to.
—Thank you. By both parties or by just the Senate?
—By the Senate.
—Thank you. The Labor Party have said that their second preferred option is Senator Harradine's amendment. They have therefore actually said that the threshold test put forward by the National Indigenous Working Group, which we consider is a considerable compromise, is not on their preference list.
We will support, as we did last year, the Mabo test proposed by the ALP last year, as this is at least in accordance with common law principles. We do not agree that this common law position on determination should be applied at the registration stage, but in categorically ruling out support for any form of physical connection test we support the ALP compromise on a compromise. The ALP clearly have put their cards on the table in that, rather than supporting the threshold test which was put forward by the National Indigenous Working Group, they prefer the physical connection test.

name: Woodley, Sen John
text:
—Senator Bolkus, simply because you say that there is a massive difference between the government bill and Senator Harradine's amendment, does not make it so. I have to say that I just cannot see how you can make that claim. I really believe that Senator Harradine is not advancing us past where the government has left us, that is, with a physical connection, which will certainly rule out many people.
I think that what Senator Harradine is doing is a slight improvement but that it breaks the absolute principle that we have been committed to and arguing about for so long, that is, that the connection should be physical or cultural or spiritual. Trying to convince us that somehow or other there is a vast gap between Senator Harradine's position and the government's position does not wash, I am afraid. 
The problem is that I do not see how including a reference to a parent of a member of the native title claim group solves the problem of stolen children. Although they may know the group from which they came, the evidence is that many of them still do not know who their actual parents are, so we still have the problem. Then, of course, it does not address the problem of wholesale removals that go back much further than one generation. I really cannot understand, Senator Bolkus, how you can say that there is a massive gap between the government's position and Senator Harradine's position. It just does not wash with me, I am afraid, even though you may say it a number of times.

name: Brown, Sen Bob
text:
—I agree with Senator Woodley. What has happened here is, firstly, that Senator Harradine's amendment removes all avenues for a connection with the land other than a physical one being a reason for a person to move towards a claim. It adds that a claim is taken to include a reference to a parent of a member of the native title claim group.
That is a slight advance on the government's position, but it leaves out uncles, aunts and grandparents—all previous generations. What we see in this amendment is what is left, but we should be looking at what has been taken out. Beyond that, it very clearly does away with the spiritual connection, the cultural connection and the traditional connection that people have with the land unless they have a physical connection argument to put forward. It is just not good enough.
The dynamics of this are that, in December last year, the non-government participants in this debate agreed to have the spiritual, cultural and physical connection test available. All other components of the non-government benches except for Senator Harradine hold firm to that. That is for him to wrestle with. The Greens cannot go along with this further removal of the ability of indigenous people to make a claim that the land is theirs when it is.
Senator Minchin might talk about all the processes that are in between, but that confuses the matter. Let us be straight about it. If we stop people at the outset, we stop them at the finish; if we stop them at the gate, we 
 stop them getting anywhere. The problem here is that, as Senator Woodley has put it, Senator Harradine's amendment is very close to the government's amendment. It is certainly much closer to the government's amendment than it is to the next Greens-Democrat amendment. That will be the real test here.
Senator Harradine's amendment has gone, as I said before—the numbers are not here for it. The real test will be whether the numbers are here for us to stick true with the test that we first supported in December last year.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—I am getting advice that there still seems to be some concern about whether Senator Harradine's amendment is in fact valid, given the way the vote went, what it added on and what it changed. Could I ask the chair to go back and look to see whether in fact Senator Harradine's amendment will work.
—Senator Harradine's proposed amendment is valid. It is an addition of 190B(11) to the section that is already in the bill.

name: Minchin, Sen Nick
text: —To clarify matters, the Senate has adopted government amendment 73 which introduces the new physical connection test in subsection (7)(b). What Senator Harradine is proposing is an amendment which would amend the bill to add to the meaning of (7)(b) which is now part of the bill. What Senator Harradine is proposing is what is in addition to that, so that for the purpose of the operation of subsection (7)(b) the reference to a member of the native title claim group would be taken to include a reference to the parent or a member of the native title claim group. So it is an interpretation of (7)(b) which the committee has just adopted.

name: Woodley, Sen John
text:
—I do not want to prolong this—I suppose I am prolonging it—but I think that Senator Margetts has a point. You see, it is not just adding; it is actually changing the government's registration test. That is why the government has indicated that it will vote 
 against it. This is the point that I think Senator Margetts is trying to push. We know how the numbers are, so I do not intend to continue this, but you can see my problem with what is being said.
—The fact is that the committee has voted to add subclauses (5) to (10) and, once that has been achieved, it is quite within the competence of the committee to add another subclause—subclause (11). In that context, it is quite valid for the amendment to be made.

name: Harradine, Sen Brian
text:
—I do not propose to respond to the statements that have been made. It is quite clear that Senator Brown is obdurate in his attitude to the truth in this matter.
—Mr Temporary Chair, on a point of order: I would like a retraction of that.
—There is no point of order, Senator Margetts.
—Mr Chairman, I rarely say those sorts of things. I make that point that before dinner I tried to outline, and Senator Bolkus and Senator Minchin both tried to outline, the facts of the situation. I ask honourable senators to focus on what Senator Brown said as to this amendment. If he wants me to show him how he is absolutely wrong in just a minimal understanding of what native title is all about, I shall be able to provide him with a little paper on it tomorrow, which I shall have incorporated into Hansard .

name: Brown, Sen Bob
text:
—It might have been my father who told me to be careful of anybody who thinks that they are the sole owners of the facts. We have a difference of opinion here.
—You should have listened to him.
—I did listen to him, and it is good advice. We have a difference of opinion here. Yes, I can be obdurate, I can stand strong when there is a further erosion of the rights of indigenous people involved in this pretty terrible process in here. We have not heard the last of it yet. We are going to 
 see more of it. If `obdurate' is a word that Senator Harradine wants to levy, I will accept it. I am not in the business of simply going weak at the knees because he and I have different interpretations. I respect his ability to stand for what he thinks are the facts and I hope he will do likewise.

name: Woodley, Sen John
text: —On another matter altogether, I realise that something very sensitive is occurring in this debate and that is that without really due recognition—we have been talking about stolen children—I am conscious of the fact that we may have in the gallery some people who come under that heading. I would like to recognise them and say that we are not just talking about theory but about the lives of people, whose lives we affect deeply. I wanted to recognise that that is so.

name: Bolkus, Sen Nick
text:
—It is probably appropriate at this stage also to very briefly repeat a point I made earlier. We are talking about the difference between the Harradine amendment and the government's position. Earlier I mentioned the Wangkangurru people of the south-east corner of the Simpson Desert in western Queensland. They were removed in the 1940s. As I said earlier, they know their sites. They are a very traditional people. They have a traditional connection to their country. They are imbued with it. They associate themselves with it. I am informed that in all cases their parents have died. So, under the government test, they would not be able to pursue their claim; under the Harradine test they would. That is why I have been saying consistently that there is a big difference if you were to take it back one generation. It is the difference between two decades or maybe five, six or seven years. That in itself demonstrates, I think, the difference between the two tests. They are not the only ones. Earlier, we mentioned people from Great Keppel, and I am sure there are quite a number of similar circumstances.
As I said earlier in the debate, our preferred position was the one that we moved and the one that did not get the support of this place. But in the same way that we have been trying to make incremental gains on what passed the parliament last year, trying to resist erosion of 
 those gains or of the position that might have got through last year, in the same way that we make a commitment to ensure that the principles we pursue now we will pursue in government, I say to the committee that though this may not be the preferred option of some—obviously, our preferred option was the one we moved—I think it would be an enormous injustice to possibly a whole generation of people if we were not to pick up the amendment.
Senator Woodley, I think you have picked the right point again in terms of stolen generations. In a sense they are covered by the `locked out' provisions, but people have been locked out in more than one way, they have been driven out in more than one way. If we acknowledge that, I think we really have to acknowledge the Harradine position. Though I would maintain that it does not cover all situations, it does cover a whole lot more than the government's does. That is the reason we are supporting it.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Harradine's ) be agreed to.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—I move:
(237)	 Schedule 2, item 63, page 205 (line 27) to page 206 (line 24), omit subsections (6), (7), (8) and (9), substitute:
	 (6)	 If the Registrar is considering placing reliance on material which is adverse to the interests of the claimant, or inconsistent with material supplied by the claimant, the claimant must be shown the material and given a reasonable opportunity to respond or supply further material.
	 (7)	 If, after receiving a response or other material from the claimant, the Registrar is satisfied that there is a genuine factual dispute with respect to the adverse or inconsistent material or a genuine legal dispute as to its effect, the Registrar must not consider the adverse or inconsistent material further.
The government proposal does not require that evidence be filed with an application; merely that the factual basis be adequately described. The amendment deletes the new requirements which do not relate to the information required to be lodged with the application but retains the prime facie test in 
 relation to material that must be lodged under section 190B.
The physical connection test is removed under section 190B(6). If the registrar is considering relying on material adverse to the claimant, the claimant must have a chance to respond. If after that there is a factual dispute the registrar must not consider the adverse material further under section 190B. The government's amendments seek to apply the new, more onerous registration test to all claims currently on the register of claims. We believe it is an unnecessary task. The National Indigenous Working Group proposed amendments focused on those instances where registration via a low threshold test may have caused problems—for instance, in overlapping claims in response to section 29 notices.
I indicate that because we have just passed amendments, including government amendment No. 73—and of course we have had discussions backwards and forwards on whether it is an amendment that has been moved or now the bill—it now means that the Greens-Democrats amendments need to be altered a little in line with the new situation. Therefore, where our amendment originally was to delete sections 6, 7, 8 and 9, I believe they will need to be renumbered 5, 7, 8 and 9. I am happy to be advised if that is not the case. This does give all participants in this debate a chance to reasssess the removal of the physical connection test. If it is believed, and it has been strongly argued by Senator Bolkus—I have to say that his arguments for his own amendments were not his most convincing—by the majority of members of this chamber that the physical connection test is not fair to indigenous people, this is the chamber's chance to address that.

name: Minchin, Sen Nick
text:
—I seek some clarification because I am a little confused. I am not sure whether this amendment purports to amend the bill as presented to the chamber or amend the bill as amended by government amendment No. 73. There was some confusion in the last debate in December about some of these matters: we were amending things that had already been 
 changed. I seek some clarification and, if necessary, amendment of the amendment, to ensure that it reflects what is now the bill before the chamber.
—I assume the intent of the amendment moved by Senator Margetts was to omit new subsections 6 to 9. Perhaps Senator Margetts can clarify that.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text: —I was hoping that changing to 5, 7, 8 and 9 would do that.

name: Bolkus, Sen Nick
text:
—Once again, this is an amendment to page 205 of the bill, line 27, `prima facie case'. That has already been amended by the preceding vote. As a consequence, amendment 237 needs to be further amended. What Senator Margetts would like to do is remove the prima facie case, which is 6, 7, 8 and 9. So, in a sense, we are probably talking about amendments to like provisions in the amendments that just went through. The impact of Senator Margetts's amendment will be the same. What we need to do is to reword 237 to say that government amendment 73 be amended to omit subsections 6, 7, 8 and 9.
—5, 7, 8 and 9.
—Okay; 5, 7, 8 and 9 and replace them with 6 and 7. While we work out the impact of that, I am sure Senator Margetts will try to tell us.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text: —What Senator Bolkus has suggested is what we are seeking to do—to omit 5, 7, 8 and 9 and replace them.

name: Bolkus, Sen Nick
text:
—I think other senators might be having the same trouble as I am with respect to this—that is, trying to work out the impact of this amendment. If we are bowling over 5 in the recently passed amendment, we are then trying to knock out `factual basis for claim native title'. If we do that, then we need to be sure as to what we will replace it with. If we are knocking out the physical connection, it does not seem to me that the Democrat-Greens amendment will replace it with all that much; in fact, I do not think there is a replacement there for it. With respect to sub 
 clause 8, `No failure to comply with section 61A', in terms of disclosure of documents, there is a document-type clause which has been proposed by the Democrats-Greens.
Also, subclause 9 under the amendment which was recently carried, provides for non-extinguishment of claim native title et cetera. There is no replacement clause for that particular provision either. Although Senator Margetts wants to move a couple of simple clauses, I think the impact of those really will be to render some unparallelled confusion in this part of the act. As a consequence, we do not support them.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text: —I am prepared to look at alternatives to that proposal. If Senator Bolkus is saying that he would support the removal of 7 and 8, perhaps I could get an answer from him as to whether that would be acceptable to him by way of amendment instead of 5, 7, 8 and 9.

name: Bolkus, Sen Nick
text: —What I am saying is that this really is not all that well thought out by the Democrats and Greens. There are intended and unintended consequences which go far in excess of what we contemplated and passed last time, and what we would be contemplating passing this time. Basically, a bit more thought to this might have worked out a more positive outcome, but to try to move these amendments now is a bit like crying over spilt milk.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—The milk was spilt when the opposition agreed to a physical connection test. Very nice trying to blame it on the Greens now; it is not working, Senator Bolkus. I move:
(237)	 Schedule 2, item 63, page 205 (line 27) to page 206 (line 24), omit subsections (5), (7), (8) and (9), substitute:
	 (6)	 If the Registrar is considering placing reliance on material which is adverse to the interests of the claimant, or inconsistent with material supplied by the claimant, the claimant must be shown the material and given a reasonable opportunity to respond or supply further material.
	 (7)	 If, after receiving a response or other material from the claimant, the Registrar 
 is satisfied that there is a genuine factual dispute with respect to the adverse or inconsistent material or a genuine legal dispute as to its effect, the Registrar must not consider the adverse or inconsistent material further.
	 Question put:
	 That the amendment (Senator Margetts's  and Senator Woodley's ) be agreed to.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text: —Greens (WA)-Democrats amendment 327A is to oppose part 4, item 11—that is, the retrospective elements. I am sure we have heard on many occasions people arguing about the injustice of retrospectivity. Here we want to remove the ability of people to retrospectively knock out claims on the basis of what many people have argued is wrong in terms of physical connection tests. Therefore, I implore the committee, I implore the Labor Party, I implore Senator Harradine and I implore all senators to remove the retrospectivity involved in this and they can do that by opposing part 4, item 11.

name: Bolkus, Sen Nick
text: —I support amendment 327A, together with amendment 328. I think Senator Margetts's amendment was deliberated upon last time and we hope it is possible to get it up this time.

name: Minchin, Sen Nick
text:
—Obviously the government does not support this amendment. We first moved the proposed 
 new registration test at the end of June 1996 by way of the introduction of a bill into the House of Representatives. What is proposed is not retrospective. It was made clear then that the new registration test would apply to all claims made after that date. That is absolutely the norm for many government actions and proposals. It certainly applies to all budget proposals. Notice was given by way of the introduction of that test then that all future claims would be subject to the new registration test, so it is not retrospective.
We now have over 700 claims in the system. Many of them, of course, are causing the very problems which indigenous groups and others have sought to have remedied by the application of a new registration test. So it makes a nonsense of the whole proposal, and I would have thought the ALP would recognise that it makes a nonsense of all of this if every single claim that is currently in the system—some 750, covering nearly 50 per cent of Australia—is immune from this test. We have all been wasting our time if that is the proposition.

name: Bolkus, Sen Nick
text: —Can I just get some clarification from Senator Margetts. The amendment you said you were moving was No. 328. If it is not that, there is some validity in Senator Minchin's argument. But it is No. 328, is it not?

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—The amendment that I am moving is No. 327A to remove the retrospectivity, and No. 328 later replaces it with a better option. It is a bit hard to replace it until we remove the existing section, so that is what we will be attempting to do.
Quite frankly, I think it is despicable to treat human rights as if it were a sales tax bill. If this is what the government is suggesting is the right thing to do, perhaps next time there is a business related bill which is not a tax bill we will see if the government treats people the same way and see what kind of response it gets. I do not think it is the right thing to do, and I thought for an instant that Labor was going to support removing that section to be replaced by No. 328. There is not a lot of point in moving No. 328 unless 
 we have opposed the existing section. Perhaps I could get some clarification on what the opposition's position is on No. 327A to oppose item 11.

name: Bolkus, Sen Nick
text:
—Our position is that No. 328 is an acceptable alternative. But looking at No. 327A, once again, to get the full ramifications of that, my understanding is that last time we did not adopt a measure like No. 327A, but we adopted the regime as reflected in No. 328. My other information is that, if the Democrat-Greens (WA) amendment No. 327A is not successful, the Democrat-Greens would move reconsideration of item 11 and move No. 328. So my information is that there is not incompatibility between not supporting No. 327A and supporting No. 328. I will double check that while the debate continues, but that is the starting point that we have.
—The question is that schedule 5, part 4, stand as printed.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

name: Woodley, Sen John
text:
—I presume that No. 327A was not successful. So, in taking up the point that Senator Bolkus has made and as it is described on the running sheet, I move reconsideration of item 11 and move amendment No. 328, which is quite a long amendment. Therein, you will notice that the Democrat-Greens (WA) amendment puts in a whole new registration regime. I move:
(328)	 Schedule 5, item 11, page 347 (line 16) to page 351 (line 11), omit subitems (3) to (11), substitute:
	 Application accepted for registration after 27 June 1996
(3)	 If an application was registered after 27 June 1996 in relation to land or waters that have not been the subject of a notice under section 29 of the old Act, or a corresponding provision of a law of a State or Territory covered by a determination under subsection 43(1) of the new Act or old Act, the relevant Minister of the State or Territory in which the land or waters are situated may request the Registrar to deal with the application or any part of it under the new Act.  

(4)	 If the Registrar agrees to accept the request under subitem (3) or a part of it, the Registrar must:
		 (a)	 refer the request to the applicant and the representative body for the area concerned; and
		 (b)	 advise the applicant and the representative body that the representative body may, within 60 days after the request is referred, certify in accordance with its certification functions (see section 203BE) the application or part identified by the Registrar (subject to any amendment made by the applicant and considered by the representative body); and
		 (c)	 if the application or part is not certified by the representative body within that period, or within a further period agreed between the Registrar and the representative body—consider the application under section 190A of the new Act.
	 Overlapping applications
(5)	 If, at the commencement of this Act, there is more than one application on the Register in relation to the same area of land or waters, the Registrar must:
		 (a)	 consider whether the native title rights and interests claimed may consistently be held by different native title groups; and
		 (b)	 as soon as is reasonably practicable, advise the applicants and the representative body or bodies for the area of his or her view and of the reasons for that view; and
		 (c)	 request them to provide information and submissions as to whether it is appropriate for the expeditious conduct of the applications and the processes of the Act that the applications be amalgamated in whole or in part; and
		 (d)	 consider any information or submissions supplied pursuant to the request; and
		 (e)	 determine whether it is appropriate for the applications to be amalgamated, in whole or in part.
(6)	 If the Registrar decides that it is appropriate that the applications be amalgamated, in whole or in part, the Registrar must:
		 (a)	 advise the applicants and the representative body or bodies for the area of that fact; and 

		 (b)	 request the applicants to amend their applications so as to ensure that:
			 (i)	 rights and interests that are common between the groups are the subject of only one application; and
			 (ii)	 separate rights and interests are the subject of other applications;
		 but only to the extent that the native title group concerned in relation to the separate rights and interests is different from the native title group in relation to the common rights and interests.
(7)	 If the Registrar notifies the applicants and the representative body or bodies referred to in subitem (6):
	 (a)	 the applicants must, within 60 days after receiving the notification, advise the Registrar whether they have been able to reach agreement as to the identity of the appropriate applicant for those rights and interests and, if they have, advise the Registrar which single application is to remain on the Register in relation to those rights and interests; and
	 (b)	 if, within that period or a longer period allowed by the Registrar, the applicants have not reached agreement, the Registrar must advise the representative body for the relevant area of that fact.
(8)	 If the representative body receives an advice under paragraph (7)(b), it must attempt by conciliation to obtain agreement between the applicants as to the identity of the appropriate applicant, and the appropriate description of the native title group on whose behalf the application is made, for the rights and interests.
(9)	 If:
		 (a)	 the representative body is not able to achieve a resolution within 6 months of the matter being referred to it by the Registrar; and
		 (b)	 either:
			 (i)	 it is satisfied that a resolution is not likely to be achieved within a reasonable time; or
			 (ii)	 a notice under section 29 of the new Act, or a corresponding provision of a law of a State or Territory covered by a determination under subsection 43(1) of the new Act, is lodged in relation to any part of the land or waters concerned;

	 the representative body must refer the matter to the arbitral body within 14 days. 

(10)	 If the representative body does not refer the matter to the arbitral body, any applicant may do so.
(11)	 If the matter is referred to the arbitral body, the arbitral body must determine:
		 (a)	 which applicant is to act for the whole of the area covered by the applications in relation to which common rights and interests are claimed (if that applicant consents to act); and
		 (b)	 redefine the native title group so that, to the greatest extent possible, those who were otherwise covered by the overlapping applications are members of the native title group of the remaining application.
(11A)	 If, under this item, a particular applicant and a set of native title rights and interests are defined, the Registrar must amend one application accordingly and remove the other applications from the Register or amend them so that they are limited to rights and interests not the subject of the common application.
(11B)	 If a notice is given under section 29 before the Register is varied under subitem (11A), except with the consent of the negotiation parties (which for this purpose includes each of the native title parties at the date on which the section 29 notice was given) the negotiations must not commence, and the relevant period specified in section 35 does not commence to run.
(11C)	 If an application is required to be dealt with under subitems (3) and (4), and subitem (5), it should be dealt with first under subitem (5).

name: Minchin, Sen Nick
text: —I was about to say my understanding was that No. 328 was conditional upon No. 327A passing, but I am being advised that that is not necessarily the case.

name: Bolkus, Sen Nick
text:
—My information is that it is conditional on No. 328, not on No. 327A failing. If one was to look at No. 327A, it would remove from pages 347 to 351 provisions applying to the registration of claims primarily with respect to pre-June 1996. Amendment No. 328 is a provision which goes to the application for registration after June 1996, and then 
 it goes to overlapping applications and so on with respect to that.
I presume that is the distinction between one and the other and what has been proposed here is a new regime for post 27 June 1996. As a consequence that is why I thought it was compatible to adopt this particular provision in respect of those applications. I do not know if the minister is getting the same advice as I am. He may not be getting the same advice as to supporting the amendment, but he may be getting the same advice as to the impact of the amendment. As I said earlier, although we are still checking this, given that we are talking here of post June 1996 and a regime which was very close to the one that we pursued during the last deliberations on this bill, we indicate that we are supporting it.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text: —Greens-Democrat amendment No. 328 deals with the retrospective review of overlapping claims and claims which are identified by the appropriate minister as potentially not satisfying the new test. The process provides in the first instance for reconsideration of claims by the applicants and representative bodies. If it does not achieve a result within a specified period, the registrar will be able to assess the claims against the new test.

name: Minchin, Sen Nick
text:
—I just indicate that we are not in a position to accept this amendment. I do not have the time to consider it in full detail, but we do not see any reason to depart from the propositions we have put as to how claims made after 27 June 1996 should be dealt with. I do not want to prolong the debate, but I indicate that we would be opposed to No. 328.
Amendment not agreed to.

name: Minchin, Sen Nick
text:
—I move:
(3)	 Schedule 1, item 9, page 14 (lines 23 to 28), omit subsection (9), substitute:
Exclusion of acts benefiting Aboriginal peoples or Torres Strait Islanders
	 (9)	 An act is not a  previous exclusive possession act  if it is: 

		 (a)	 the grant or vesting of any thing that is made or done by or under legislation that makes provision for the grant or vesting of such things only to, in or for the benefit of, Aboriginal peoples or Torres Strait Islanders; or
		 (b)	 the grant or vesting of any thing expressly for the benefit of, or to or in a person to hold on trust expressly for the benefit of, Aboriginal peoples or Torres Strait Islanders; or
		 (c)	 the grant or vesting of any thing over particular land or waters, if at the time a thing covered by paragraph (a) or (b) is in effect in relation to the land or waters.
		 Note:	 The expression  Aboriginal peoples  is defined in section 253.
Exclusion of national parks etc.
	 (9A)	 An act is not a  previous exclusive possession act  if the grant or vesting concerned involves the establishment of an area, such as a national, State or Territory park, for the purpose of preserving the natural environment of the area.
Effect of exclusions
	 (9B)	 To avoid doubt, the fact that an act is, because of any of the previous subsections, not a previous exclusive possession act does not imply that the act is not valid.
(4)	 Schedule 1, item 9, page 19 (after line 21), at the end of Division 2B, add:
23JA  Attribution of certain acts
	 If:
		 (a)	 a previous exclusive possession act or a previous non-exclusive possession act took place before the establishment of a particular State, the Jervis Bay Territory, the Australian Capital Territory or the Northern Territory; and
		 (b)	 the act affected land or waters that, when this section commences, form part of the State or Territory;
		 then, for the purposes of this Division, the act is taken to be attributable to:
		 (c)	 the State; or
		 (d)	 if the Territory is the Jervis Bay Territory—the Commonwealth; or
		 (e)	 if the Territory is the Australian Capital Territory or the Northern Territory—that Territory.
		 Note:	 The meaning given to the expression  attributable  by section 239 will 
 apply for the purposes of this Division to all other previous exclusive and non-exclusive possession acts.
(5)	 Schedule 1, item 12A, page 123 (lines 3 and 4), omit subparagraph (1)(b)(ii), substitute:
	 (ii)	 the area is held expressly for the benefit of, or is held on trust, or reserved, expressly for the benefit of, Aboriginal peoples or Torres Strait Islanders; and
(6)	 Schedule 1, item 12A, page 123 (line 13), omit "creation of the trust", substitute "doing of the thing that resulted in the holding".
(7)	 Schedule 1, item 12A, page 123 (line 16), omit "on trust".
(8)	 Schedule 1, item 12A, page 124 (line 13), omit "declaration", substitute "dedication".
(9)	 Schedule 1, item 49, page 140 (line 24), omit paragraph (1)(a), substitute:
		 (a)	 anything set out in Schedule 1, other than:
			 (i)	 a mining lease; or
			 (ii)	 an interest created by or under legislation that creates interests only for the benefit of Aboriginal peoples or Torres Strait Islanders; or
			 (iii)	 an interest created expressly for the benefit of, or held on trust expressly for the benefit of, Aboriginal peoples or Torres Strait Islanders; or
			 (iv)	 any other interest created in relation to particular land or waters, if at the time an interest covered by subparagraph (ii) or (iii) is in effect in relation to the land or waters; or
(10)	 Schedule 1, item 49, page 141 (after line 3), at the end of section 249C, add:
Regulations to cover exclusive possession interests only
	 (3)	 Before the Governor-General makes a regulation for the purposes of paragraph (1)(b) declaring a particular interest to be a Scheduled interest, the Minister must be satisfied that the interest confers a right of exclusive possession that extinguishes all native title rights and interests over the land or waters concerned.
Government amendment 3 will replace subsection 23B(9) with a new subsection that ensures that certain acts, including grants specifically for the benefit of Aboriginal people, are excluded from the confirmation of extinguishment provisions. Government amendment 4 rectifies a gap in the confirmation of extinguishment provisions by 
 enabling a state or territory to confirm the effect of previous exclusive possession acts and previous non-exclusive possession acts that took place over land that now forms part of that state or territory but did not at the time the grant was made. Amendments 5 to 7 make minor amendments to section 47A to ensure that that provision, which enables certain extinguishing acts to be ignored when a native title claim is being determined, applies to areas which have been granted or vested, whether on trust or otherwise, expressly for the benefit of indigenous people.
Government amendment No. 8 replaces the word `declaration' in section 47B with the word `dedication', simply to ensure that the terminology used in 47B to refer to land reserved for a purpose is consistent with the terminology used elsewhere in the bill when referring to reserved land. Both amendments 9 and 10 affect the definition of `scheduled interest' set out in proposed section 249C in the bill: the grant of a scheduled interest before 23 December 1996 can be confirmed to have extinguished native title.
We are putting these amendments in good faith. We think they should be supported by the Senate; the confirmation regime was passed through the Senate last time. These amendments do pick up some anomalies which we have identified in discussions with all the other parties and with the various interests. While there may be those in the chamber who do not like the confirmation provisions at all, I would have thought they would see these as acceptable and sensible improvements to the confirmation regime.

name: Bolkus, Sen Nick
text:
—The opposition had enormous problems with this extinguishment regime last time and those problems really have not gone away. The government here has undertaken a speculative exercise of attempting to predict what the courts may decide about the extinguishing effect of inconsistent grants of interest on native title.
The government describes this section as confirmation of extinguishment, implying that these provisions merely confirm the common law position. However, it is clear to all of us on this side of the debate that these provisions 
 do in fact overreach the common law and in themselves are legislative extinguishment of native title. The government, for instance, says that people have assumed that such interests as freehold, all types of leases, public works, et cetera, extinguish native title. But I think it is clear to say that the Wik decision left this assumption in a very unclear situation. The government says it needs to make clear which interests extinguish native title. However, this is very much a bad description of the effect of its legislation. It is misleading.
The process, for instance, by which the government has unilaterally determined what will extinguish native title is shoddy. It was exposed as such by parliamentary committee after parliamentary committee, and the process will result in the extinguishment of native title throughout the country with consequent compensation implications for the taxpayer. This is a provision that also rejects the principle adopted by Wik: the principle of coexistence. In terms of the general outline of this provision, what we have here are bucketloads of extinguishment: we have them by way of division 2B for instance.
The only justification for a legislative extinguishment regime is to allow development and interest to be granted over land without having to consider native title at all. To us, that is unacceptable. Extinguishment is not necessary for validation of titles or protection of the existing valid interests in the land. These interests do prevail already over native title; case after case has indicated that as well. What we have here is legislation with a sole purpose of ensuring that future interests can take place unimpeded in any way by native title. What we have here is not just extinguishment; we have discriminatory extinguishment. We have extinguishment also when, as I said, the common law leaves open whether it is suspension or extinguishment.
As I said, the principles of the Wik case are overturned by this particular part of the government's 10-point plan. The government, for instance, has attempted to ensure that native title will be partially extinguished by the grant of a non-exclusive possession act, a pastoral lease. Recognising this injustice, the Senate voted last December in favour of the 
 amendments by Senator Harradine which confirmed the position at common law—namely, that native title is suppressed and not extinguished by the grant of a pastoral lease. We continue to support those amendments. When one looks at what extinguishes native title, when one looks at what the government has tried to ensure extinguishes native title, one finds a long, exhaustive list of interests such as rifle ranges, Defence purposes and water tanks. It is amazing to what extent the government has gone to find ways of extinguishing native title.
We say now that there still needs to be a focus on the government's approach to legislative extinguishment. We say the government still exceeds the common law. The claim that division 2B is intended to reflect the common law is still wrong. For instance, section 23J gives that game away. Section 23J says that compensation is payable where the legislation goes beyond the common law and extinguishes native title. It is a safety net provision but one that basically is a confession by the government that they go in excess of the common law.
 In relation to the schedule of extinguishing interests, Senator Minchin says there are some 60,000 leases in division 2B, many of them in the schedule. Yet the way that schedule was drawn up, the way people's native title rights were extinguished on such a massive scale behind—as we found out—closed doors was in direct violation of the methodology made painstakingly clear by the High Court in the Wik decision. The judges of the court said that, when you are dealing with people's property rights and asking the extinguishment question, you must look carefully, firstly, at the legislation which authorises Crown grants; secondly, at the individual lease documents given to land holders to ascertain the precise rights; and, thirdly, at the native title rights which the local people assert over the land.
It is only then that you can come to a conclusion about inconsistency and extinguishment. But the Native Title Act left the extinguishment question to the courts and the common law to decide on a fair and just basis according to law. This government's proposal has ignored the detail of what was demanded 
 by the court. Basically what we have here is a check list which will, I am sure, throw up error after error.
 The other important aspect in this debate is the question of constitutional validity. Eminent lawyer after eminent lawyer has told parliamentary committees that lack of notification associated with division 2B acquisitions of property was a matter of constitutional concern. If indigenous Australians are not notified before their property rights are acquired and they are not given an opportunity to object, how can the bill be said to provide just terms and pass the procedural aspects of the just terms constitutionality test?
 We continue to say the government's earlier overreach is a concern. The government, as Senator Minchin has said, is moving amendments. Some amendments will curtail the overreach in one of two ways. Subsection 9 of 23B will be widened so that it excludes all the appropriate forms of beneficial land ownership and trust or for the benefit of indigenous people, and areas created by divesting or grants to protect the national environment such as national parks have been excluded. These are beneficial amendments. As a consequence, we will support them.
 Our amendments still go to the protection against overreach, for instance, in the definition of previous exclusive possession act. We also go to the question of 23B and the extinguishment as well. I say at this stage that the Greens-Democrats amendment to oppose division 2B is one that we will support when it comes up for a vote. We supported it last time, but, as the Senate knows, we were beaten by the numbers in that respect.
 I also say that we have taken the government and the High Court at their word in respect of factors that are relevant in terms of section 23B and defining acts which the government says extinguish native title. Proposed subsection 9B excludes from the definition of a previous exclusive possession act a category of act which, in our view, cannot be included on any fair or reasonable basis. It excludes leases which exceed 25,000 hectares. The High Court said in Wik that the size of the lease in question was a very relevant consideration in deciding whether a 
 particular grant extinguishes native title. In fact, even the government agrees. It lists size as one of the 10 relevant factors in its explanatory memorandum.
 Taking the government and the High Court to word, we say that 25,000 hectares is a very large area in anyone's language. It is impossible how anyone could argue that every lease of that dimension would necessarily require exclusive possession in order to give effect to the grant. Excluding such grants does not mean that individual lease holders of large properties are prevented from proving in court that their particular grant necessarily implies exclusive possession. It simply means that we want to protect against the government sweeping every one of these very large grants indiscriminately into the extinguishing category.
 There are other amendments as well which we will pursue, but, as I say, there are both constitutional and fairness problems in respect of the government's proposals put up the first time and also put up this time. We will be pursuing amendments once again to ensure that we protect the position that was passed in the Senate last year.

name: Boswell, Sen Ronald
text:
—The opposition's amendment is quite ridiculous. They want to remove certain lease holders from the definition of exclusive possession simply on the basis of the size of the lease. They are taking it upon themselves to set an arbitrary figure of 25,000 hectares. I do not know how they reached 25,000 hectares. Why not make it 40,000 hectares? Why not make it 50,000 hectares? If it is an exclusive possession, it is exclusive possession. Exclusive possession is not determined by the size of the lease. I think they have simply plucked a number out of the air. If there is one lease in Queensland that is 25,000 hectares exactly and there is another one that is 25,000.82 hectares—0.82 hectares is about the size of a normal household block; and the person that is sitting on the 25,000 hectares is probably out too—
—Twenty-five thousand hectares is a normal block? Do you live in Texas? 
—I said 0.82 of a hectare. One lease is 25,000 hectares and the other is 25,000.82 hectares. You take an arbitrary figure and the people who fall on one side of the line are in and the other ones are out.
A perpetual lease is a perpetual lease and it is not determined by the size; it is determined by the way the lease was issued. Those leases—of 25,000 hectares and more—have been included in the exclusive possession schedule. I cannot see any reason why some arbitrary decision would be made to exclude anything over 25,000 hectares. It really has no bearing on the connection to the Wik decision at all. There were two test cases on the leases in Wik: one was 289,820 hectares and the smaller one was 138,560 hectares. They are a long way from the 25,000 hectares that the government has decided to put in the category of native title.
I think it is a quite silly and stupid amendment. I do not know how the figure of 25,000 was reached. Perhaps Senator Bolkus might tell us the way he reached it. Did he look into a crystal ball or did he come up with it some other way?

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text: —There is some clarification I need from Senator Bolkus in relation to opposition amendment N3. There is some conflict with Greens-Democrats amendment 12A. I would like to ask him—and I hope he has time to answer—what is the effect of opposition N3? What would be the reason for not supporting our 12A instead? N3 seems to be extinguishing crown to crown grants on titles that come under a number of categories, including residential and other categories. I wonder if Senator Bolkus can explain the rationale for not supporting 12A instead of his N3.

name: Bolkus, Sen Nick
text:
—Very briefly, as Senator Margetts rightly said, N3 is a modified version of an amendment which passed the Senate last year. It is an amendment which again corrects the overreach in the definition of a `previous exclusive possession act'. It excludes, for instance, grants of an interest between different arms of what is the same basic entity—for 
 instance, crown to crown—whether it be a statutory authority or a state or federal government. It applies the same exclusion of the criteria of vesting of an interest in land in the same entities. Proposed subsection 9A of 23B also contains an appropriate protection where the land is subsequently put to residential, agricultural or commercial uses. At this point the exclusion no longer applies.
The amendment also leaves it to the common law to determine what effect on native title those transfers between different arms of government—crown to crown—have. It is something that I think we pursued last time. We did not want to preclude a non-extinguishment capacity by adopting the extinguishment principle adopted by the government. It also maintains consistency with the current Native Title Act, which excluded these interests from the automatic extinguishment category.
So the advice is that, in essence, it does what we set out to do last time, but it has been amended probably more in style than anything else to pick up some of the technical problems with it. Given the fact that it is 45 seconds before 9.50 p.m. now, I should take on notice any further information which would clarify the modification. As I say, the substance is the same. It is an amendment which was developed by the indigenous working group lawyers and ourselves in consultation with other parties. My understanding is that, in essence and in substance, it does no different to what was passed last time. If I can talk for five more seconds and take the rest of the answer on notice for tomorrow morning, that would probably be a fair conclusion to the day's proceedings.
Progress reported.

name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
text:
—I want to 
 take a couple of minutes of the Senate's time tonight to speak of a great Australian who passed away recently. The former mayor of Mount Isa Franz Born died during the week of 27 March and was buried in Caloundra. He was the mayor of Mount Isa from 1975 to 1985 and was involved in a number of significant community projects, including the construction of the Mount Isa Civic Centre and library and Lake Julius.
Through the auspices of the North West Star newspaper I have learnt of some of the tributes paid to the late Franz Born by friends and community leaders, including the current mayor Ron McCullough, Mr Fred Binzer and Mr Joe Schmider who gave some overview of the work that Mr Born did in the north-west during his time. Franz Born will be remembered as a great citizen of Mount Isa and of the north-west. A perfectionist in all he did, Mr Born came to Mount Isa in the early 1950s, travelling on a motorbike via dirt roads, after he had emigrated from Germany.
Attracted by the employment prospects, he took up a position as an underground miner and quickly progressed to foreman before leaving the mine to set up Mount Isa's brickworks—the first in Mount Isa. The business still survives in that city. He also built the Sunset Shopping Centre, which he used as a base for his smallgoods factory. That factory enabled him to draw on the skills he had learned as an apprentice butcher in Germany.
Mr Born was instrumental in the establishment of the Concordia Club in Mount Isa, which celebrated the strength of the German-Austrian migrant community in that city. His community service was recognised with the presentation of a Class 4 badge of merit by the Federal Republic of Germany during his time in Mount Isa. His entry into local politics as mayor of that mining city in the north-west was a logical progression of his community commitment.
I first met Franz Born in the early 1980s. Regrettably, I met him only very briefly when he was elected to the Liberal Senate team in Queensland at that time. He was not successful, being a little way down the ticket, but I often think that it was probably because of the influence that he and his supporters in the 
 north had at that time in getting him on to the ticket that eventually led to my election, coming from the north, to lead the Liberal Party Senate team from Queensland.
After Franz Born left the mayoralty of Mt Isa, he moved to Caloundra in semi-retirement but continued his interest in local politics there. He was involved in the Caloundra Shire Council for several years. I am told he spent two terms there and my colleague Mr Peter Slipper, the member for the federal electorate that takes in Caloundra, has told me that Mr Born was well remembered for the distinctive and attractive design work that was done in Bullcock Street, one of the main city centre streets in Caloundra. A smallgoods manufacturing plant that he started on the Sunshine Coast is still operating and, despite changing hands, has maintained its original name of Franz Smallgoods.
Mr Born is survived by his wife Cobi and children Sonja, Brigitte, Martina and Frank. I think that the Senate should recognise the work of a great Australian, a person who did a tremendous amount of work in the north and north-west for his community and for the region generally. I extend, I am sure on behalf of all Queensland senators and, in fact, on behalf of senators generally, my condolences to his wife and family.
Madam President, in the couple of extra minutes of time left available to me, I would like to mention to senators a matter that I know will be of great importance to them—and I am sure they already know about it—and that is that 21 March of this year marked the 50th anniversary of Australia's research expeditions to Macquarie Island in the Great Southern Ocean.
Macquarie Island is a sub-Antarctic island located in the Southern Ocean at a latitude of 54 degrees 30 minutes south and 158 degrees 57 minutes east. It is 1,500 kilometres south-east of Tasmania and 1,300 kilometres north of the Antarctic continent. Macquarie Island is 34 kilometres long and five kilometres wide at its widest point. It has a total surface area of 128 square kilometres. It is part of the state of Tasmania and is a state reserve managed by the Tasmanian Parks and Wildlife Service.
Discovery of the island is attributed to Captain Frederick Hasselborough who on the brig Perseverance sighted it whilst on a sealing voyage out of Sydney in July 1810. It was named after the then governor of New South Wales, Lachlan Macquarie. This discovery was to lead to extensive exploitation of the local fauna and by the end of that year bases had been established on the island to take fur seals for their skins and elephant seals for their oil. These commercial activities had a devastating effect on the seal and penguin populations, with some species still recovering.
During Sir Douglas Mawson's visit from 1911 to 1914, the first scientific station was established on the island and, in addition to conducting geomagnetic observations and mapping the island, studies were made of the island's botany, zoology, meteorology and geology. The Macquarie Island expedition also established the first radio link between Australia and Antarctica by setting up a radio relay station on Wireless Hill that could communicate with Mawson's main expedition group at Commonwealth Bay and also with the Australian mainland.
The island was declared a wildlife sanctuary in 1933 and, with the establishment of the Tasmanian National Parks and Wildlife Service in 1971, became a conservation area. It was upgraded to a state reserve in 1972 and in 1978 was renamed the Macquarie Island Nature Reserve. The Howard government nominated Macquarie Island for inscription on the World Heritage List in June 1996 and the nomination, which was made jointly with the Tasmanian government, was actually inscribed on the World Heritage List on 3 December 1997.
Macquarie Island is the oldest continuously occupied ANARE station below 50 degrees south.
Senator Robert Ray interjecting—
—I know you are very interested in this, Senator Ray.
—I am; I am paying attention.
—We as Australians can be proud of the work that is 
 undertaken at Macquarie Island and elsewhere by members of Australia's Antarctic program. The research work undertaken in some of the world's most difficult conditions is both of international and of practical importance. I was pleased to be able to participate in the commemoration of this significant anniversary of one of the world's most remote and special places. It was with some pride that,  on behalf of the Australian government and the Australian people—by telecommunications, because I was not there myself—I unveiled on 21 March 1998 a plaque commemorating the 50th anniversary of the station. I commend the great work that all the expeditioners who have worked for Australia over those years have done in that very remote place. It is one of the places that we are very proud of, and I am sure all senators join with me in congratulating all of those who have served on Macquarie Island over the past 50 years.
